session-title: Regional Identity in Modern Chinese Literature
text: How do writers, performers, poets, and filmmakers mediate between particular localities, neighboring regions, and broader notions of Chineseness in their representations of Chinese regional identities? And how do the emerging conversations shed light on changing relationships between region and capital, the local and national, and North and South China? Looking at poems, ballads, novels, films, and TV dramas from diverse regions across China and beyond in light of recent studies of regional representation, poetics, eco-literature, and the role of language and dialect in identity formation, this panel explores insider and outsider views of place and what happens when regions transgress borders. The panelists examine how nineteenth century drum ballads formed a literary geography of North China that shifted from a sense of belonging in a unified world of empire to an emphasis on the local, how borderland poets from southwest China and North-East India use imagery and themes of cultural and ecological change to convey new senses of being, place, and identity, how educated urban narrators in interactions between Putonghua-speaking sent-down youth and dialect-speaking locals negotiate local languages in contemporary film and fiction, and how gendered representations of northern Shaanxi men and women in recent novels and TV dramas serve as discursive sites for broader discussions of cultural exchange and rebirth in China. In each case, the changing depictions of the familiar and unfamiliar suggest evolving senses of place and identity during Chinas recent history.

session-title: Ritual Design in China
text: Transdisciplinary discussions on ritual from the angles of performativity, visuality, and materiality have continued to renew the subject of study over the past two to three decades. Some of the key questions raised have yet to be fully addressed in the study of rituals in China. How is ritual a performative practice? When vision is understood as socially constructed, how does it change the way we think about ritual display? What roles do materials play in ritual? This panel reframes these and other issues - the making of self-identities, exertion of authority, and maintenance of social order - as ritual design. Examining diverse source materials that range from Yinxu oracle bones and grave goods, early Chinese discussions of clothing and textiles, Kitan ceremonial attire, and Yuan court ceramics, this panel asks how the study of ritual objects, their material qualities, and their functions in the production of ritual acts, can be enriched by the conceptual framework of ritual design. Our format of inquiry, which is discussion-based and workshop-style, departs from the orthodox paper presentation model. Participants will first provide a short description of their source material and concisely address the question, what is ritual design in China? The panelists will then comment on each others pre-circulated work-in-progress papers and discuss the value of ritual design as a methodological approach.

session-title: Wenchuan Earthquake: A Decade of Changes and Continuities
text: This roundtable marks the 10-year anniversary of the biggest disaster in Chinas recent history, the Wenchuan Earthquake, which transformed state-society relations, crisis management and ideology work. In the immediate post-quake aftermath, the unprecedented outpouring of social compassion, volunteerism, rise of NGOs and open media coverage appeared to mark the long anticipated emergence of civil society in China. These brief intervals of possibility flickered out as the Party-state embarked on a top-down process of reconstruction, moral performance, and legitimation. The state at once exhibited responsiveness and deployed its repressive apparatus to silence grieving parents whose children were crushed underneath shoddily-constructed tofu-dreg schoolhouses, and to censor the media. To this day, the Wenchuan disaster remains a sensitive subject to investigate. Our panelists will discuss, from a variety of disciplinary and methodological perspectives, the different Chinas that emerged, and were buried, during the earthquake and its aftermath, distilling the shifts and continuities in Chinas modes of governance and state-society dynamics. As a former NPR correspondent during the Wenchuan earthquake, our chair, Louisa Lim, is uniquely positioned to moderate the roundtable. All the other participants will draw from their recent books, entirely or partially devoted to the study of the disaster. Christian Sorace will discuss the earthquake from the perspective of the Communist Partys legitimation strategies and concern with image-building. Kang Yi will trace the development trajectory of different types of non-governmental organizations and discuss the fluid NGO-state relationship during the eight years after the earthquake. Bin Xu will discuss how the earthquake revealed both the strength and weakness of ordinary Chinese citizens volunteering under an authoritarian state and how the disaster has been remembered and forgotten in political and cultural practices. Maria Repnikova will explain how the earthquake served at once as a turning point for media-state relations and as a dramatic example of the contradictions in states crisis management that ensue to this day. Everett Zhang will discuss how survivors resentment regarding the deaths of school children was informed by and reinforced a different sense of natural disaster and justice in China from that present in the 1976 Tangshan Earthquake.

session-title: Collaboration, Competition and Intelligentsia Circle for a New China Horizon
text: Intellectual ideas are never produced in a vacuum. It emerges from debates, collaboratively or contestably, across cultures and continents. This panel explores the formation of intelligentsia circles that takes the form of both cooperation and competition with their intellectual other, whereby new linguistic dispositions, conceptual apparatus, and modes of explicating patterns are formed. Four papers echo on the concept of shared horizon, expounded by Peter Gordon, while focusing on the different possible content of the proposition What is China, in relation to the framework of traditional Sinology and modern Chinese studies. DesForgess paper studies the Qing academics who downplayed the instrumental purpose of the civil examination system to inquire into an analytical understanding of the systems inner strength. The format of these inquiries was as radical as those produced by the learned societies in Europe. Saarelas paper explores the dialectical vision reflected through a group of European Sinological grammaticians on deciphering the Manchu language in the academic arena. The paper concludes that this effort has finally taken stride when individual animosity was discarded. Kwan discusses the hostility conjured during the race of understanding China by the British and the French imperial interpreters in the nineteenth century. Using the firsthand experiences with the local Chinese people, the British shaped a new phase of Chinese studies in Anglophone world.  Chen argues for a subtle collaboration of appropriating the Athenian legacy by both sides of Chinas 1920s cultural war, which underlined rediscovery and reincarnation of classical Chinese heritage in Chinas post-classical age.

session-title: Chinese Practices of Intellectual Property
text: The rampant imitation, counterfeiting, and falsification of goods in contemporary China have led to vehement debates over understandings of intellectual property. On the one hand, China has been condemned for failing to guarantee the protections like Western copyright law has done; on the other hand, Chinese culture has been excused for privileging tradition over creativity and communal possession over individual rights. While these two positions appear to be at odds, they proceed from the same assumption: that China did not have an indigenous concept of intellectual property before the arrival of modern international law from the West at the beginning of the twentieth century. Challenging this predominant view, this panel explores concepts and practices related to intellectual property that have emerged along with the rapid expansion of the market from the sixteenth to the early twentieth centuries. Integrating textual, visual, and material evidence, the panelists explore the formation of trademarks and copyrights, examining how these practices were mediated through inscriptions, portraits of the publisher, silk loom-marks, and seals and stamps. As a starting point to discuss hitherto unexplored Chinese practices of intellectual property, this panel aims to move beyond merely adding non-Western materials. It will also shed light on the historical contingencies behind the development of modern intellectual property by reexamining far-reaching contests over originality and authenticity, authorship and craft, and the shifting values assigned to words and things in pre-twentieth century China.

session-title: Political Socialization of Elite Chinese Students: A Trans-disciplinary Approach
text: How do the party and state institutions in the surviving communist systems manage to attract young and educated recruits and guarantee their lifelong commitment to a political career? This question is particularly relevant in investigating evolving communist systems, such as post-Mao China, where revolutionary ideology no longer functions as a key structuring element and where a liberalized employment market provides ambitious young individuals with many attractive career options beyond the party-state bureaucracy. This panel tackles this question by looking at various forms of political socialization for Chinese students. From the high school to the end of graduate studies, we unveil various mechanisms which transform students perceptions of their professional paths, influence their trajectories, and eventually cultivate their commitment to a career in the party-state. Each of the four papers investigates various mechanisms and hierarchies within school systems in which students are incorporated, including the Party organizations in high schools and universities, as well as its youth organizations, which maintain a management monopoly over students extracurricular activities in schools. Because our central interest is in elite renewal, the papers focus mainly on the countrys best high schools and universities, which provide the most cadres to the Party-State. The papers methods vary from experimental research to ethnographic observation, and their analytical approaches range from the sociology of education to the study of informal political ties. Thus, while they all treat the issue of political socialization, they offer a diversity of perspectives.

session-title: Slaves And/or Servants: Human Bondage in Chinas States and Societies over the
text: This panel examines the role of slavery in Chinese history, a generally neglected topic. Lack of scholarship on human bondage, as Robin Yates has noted previously, has led China to be overlooked in the burgeoning field of slavery in world history. Yates begins the panel by considering recently unearthed legal and administrative documents of the Qin and Han dynasties. His paper grapples with challenges of definition, particularly distinguishing between slaves, servants, and other low-status individuals in private households and state service. Jonathan Skaff also utilizes excavated sources, Tang Dynasty slave contracts and travel permits. The latter mention slaves, servants, and other Silk Road travelers. He finds that slaves of foreign and domestic origin supplied the majority of labor to elite Tang households and supplemented the profits of Inner Asian merchants. Like Skaff, Don Wyatts paper reveals that slavery in China was entangled with practices of greater Eurasia. The victorious Jurchen Jin army profited from the enslavement of the defeated Northern Song populace in 1127. Moreover, during the Mongol Empire, Turk warriors and Korean females were trafficked over long distances. Johanna Ransmeiers paper on the late Qing and early Republican periods argues that lines between slaves, servants and wives all outsiders who were integrated into households contractually were unclear. This underlying problem, together with Marxist approaches to Chinese history, served to obscure the persistence of slavery and need for emancipation into the twentieth-century. Finally, the discussant, Pamela Crossley, who also has engaged in research on slavery, will offer her insights.

session-title: Reevaluating the Coalescence and Evolution of Chinese Verse Forms
text: This panel will diachronically explore the processes by which Chinese verse forms coalesce and evolve. It will shed light on the material, compositional, and critical practices that underlie the evolution of rhyming verse in China, and reevaluate the bounds of poetry and literature as these terms translate Chinese textual forms. While one may consider shi, fu, or other categories of rhyming verse as bounded or implicitly static categories, at least two recent developments in the field have begun to erode this assumption: first, rhyming verse texts have been newly discovered in manuscripts that defy both thematic norms and bibliographic schemes of classification; second, meta-critical perspectives that examine processes of composition, critique, compilation, imitation, and forgery have revealed both the emergence of genres and deflections in the prototypical theme, topic or form of readily identified genres. The panel seeks to employ these new sources and methodological perspectives to rethink the history of Chinese versification. David Lebovitz (University of Chicago) will employ manuscript sources to explore the problems of categorizing verse forms prior to Han bibliographies; Thomas Mazanec (UC Santa Barbara) will investigate the coherence of early medieval zan around an anti-lyrical poetics of exteriority; Su Fu (Princeton) will probe the redefinition of the sao genre in critical readings of the Song dynasty; and Feiran Du (Harvard) will discuss the boundaries between poetry and prose in Song criticism. David Schaberg (UCLA) will serve as discussant and Paul W. Kroll (University of Colorado, Boulder) will chair the panel.

session-title: Of Performativity and Parody: Cultural Politics in Contemporary China
text: This four-speaker panel investigates the political ramifications of studying Chinese popular culture as it travels across geographical boundaries and academic disciplines. Through an analysis of four performance genres - online videos, experimental theater, film, and television series - this panel seeks to expand the current understanding of cultural politics in contemporary China. Taking, as a case study, Papi Jiang, Chinas most popular Internet celebrity in 2016, Jie Zhang delineates the ways in which Papi Jiangs shrewd appropriation of media conventions contributes to the viral dissemination of her self-made videos. Delving into Meng Jinghuis use of metatheater over a span of two decades, Hongjian Wang provides new analytical angles from which to explicate Mengs controversial transition from an avant-garde director to one catering to the mainstream market. By analyzing the transmutations of male bodies in the series A Chinese Odyssey (1995-2015), Jun Lei demonstrates how a gendered approach to Stephen Chows movies sheds new light on understanding identity politics in Hong Kong. Finally, Shaohua Guo examines Fated to Love You (2008), one of the most popular Taiwanese idol dramas, and argues that the dramas trans-regional appeal is largely attributable to its calculated endeavor to mediate geopolitical relations among Taiwan, Hong Kong, and mainland China.    All four studies address how performativity and parody are appropriated in diverse media spaces, while highlighting the intricate interplay of media conventions, technological affordances, and collective and individual actors in jointly shaping the cultural dynamics in contemporary China.

session-title: Literary Anthologies and Information Management in Imperial China
text: In China, literary anthologies have long mediated between what Margaret Cohen and Franco Morretti have called the great unread and its canonical fraction. Despite this key role, however, anthologies have not received as much scholarly attention as they deserve. The most well-known have been viewed as too facile and derivative to merit serious study, and the less well-known have defied traditional methods of textual scholarship by virtue of their sheer quantity. Drawing inspiration from the field of information management, our panel conceptualizes the anthologys function in terms of compressing, ordering, and regulating readers access to literary documents, and explores how this function reflected and structured new understandings of literature and literary history. Tians paper traces a long-term shift in how anthologies arranged their selections, describing the breakdown of older classification systems and the new notion of literature that emerged. Chens paper dives into a mass of now forgotten ancient-style poetry anthologies produced in the late imperial period, mapping their citation practices and proposing a new method for measuring the impact of individual anthologies. Patterson and Clifford, in contrast, focus on two famous and still widely used anthologies, comparing them with their competitors and delineating the arguments implicit in their purportedly neutral mode of simplification. Our papers range across historical periods and move comfortably between multiple scales of analysis. Together, we initiate a conversation on the role of anthologies which might be productively expanded to a broader East Asian context, and which speaks to a digital turn in recent literary scholarship.

session-title: Unreconciled Memories:  Oral Histories of the Cultural Revolution
text: It has been over half a century since the launch of the Cultural Revolution (1966-1976) in China and people who have experienced it are now aged and aging, yet no consensus has been reached about its origin, consequences, and aftermath. Instead, nostalgia and amnesia in contemporary China threaten to bury the truth of this notorious historical event. Responding to the urgency of saving memories, the East Asian Library at the University of Pittsburgh launched a CR/10 (Cultural Revolution/10 minutes) Project in late 2016, collecting short interviews of people from different ages, professions, family backgrounds, and geographical locations that bring to light a multitude of narratives and perspectives about the memories of the Cultural Revolution. The ongoing CR/10 project is the first digital archive on the subject that will be used for teaching and research. This innovative and interdisciplinary roundtable will revolve around the screening of selected CR/10 interviews, followed by discussions among scholars in history, literature, sociology, and information science regarding the crystalline memories of the Cultural Revolution. Discussants have begun receiving recordings of the interviews, while subtitling in English and editing proceed. Discussants will bring their own expertise to comment on the significance of the CR/10 project in particular, and oral history in general. For instance, Rongqian Ma (Library) will demonstrate how the digital archive in the library will help teaching and research and preserve memories of the Cultural Revolution; Paul Pickowicz (History) will incorporate his own filmed interviews on the subject to question the simplified victimization narrative and class-based interpretation to uncover the complex nature of his historical event; and Guobin Yang (Sociology) will discuss how the CR/10 project sheds light on the meanings of revolutionary tradition and political culture for the Cultural Revolution generation as well as the powerful influences of this political culture on their behavior in the Red Guard movement. As a whole, this roundtable discussion will address the crisis of memory and explore various perspectives, methodologies, and ways of collaborating to deal with controversial histories such as that of the Cultural Revolution.

session-title: Rereading Qing History Through Diaries
text: How do we read and use diaries as historical sources? Recent publishing and database projects in China have created accessibility to diaries of both notables and relative unknowns. But even as diaries suggest tantalizing access to secret conversations and hidden motivations, they overwhelm with social complexities, coded language, and mundane routines. The papers on this panel consider late Qing diaries in light of governance, rebellion, diplomacy, and reform. As the papers demonstrate, diarists involved with official bureaucracies and projects had diverse personal, emotional, and official motivations for keeping daily records. Bingyu Zheng will explore ethnicity and urban space through the descriptions of daily life, routines and relationships in the diary of an adopted bannerman in nineteenth-century Beijing. Emily Mokros will consider the information-gathering techniques and emotional allegiances of a low-level capital official during the ravages of the mid-nineteenth-century rebellions. Jenny Huangfu Day will focus on global and domestic influences in late Qing envoy reports, reflecting transition away from the travelogues distinctive of early Qing envoys. Ke Ren will read a late Qing scholarly diary to map the intersections between political and publishing circles centered in Nanjing. Andrea S. Goldman, who has used diaries extensively in her work on Qing urban culture and politics, will comment on the papers. In addition to generating a conversation about how personal voices connect to overarching political narratives, each panelist will foreground primary sources by describing reading strategies and the limitations and advantages of diaristic sources.

session-title: Beyond Literacy: Womens Pluralistic Approach to Cultural and Political
text: Womens liberation was at the core of the modernization agenda of twentieth-century Chinese reformists, revolutionaries, and social activists, within which female literacy was highly emphasized and has figured prominently in modern Chinese historiography. How women navigated the changing social environment and defined themselves is a question requiring further study. Drawing papers from the fields of History, Art History, Performance Studies, and Film Studies, this panel suggests that women oftentimes mobilized more diverse means oral, aural, visual, bodily, and cinematic to engage culture and politics and thus configure the image and ethics of woman in a vibrant and constantly changing way. Focusing on rural womens literacy learning experiences in 1930s and 1940s north China, our first paper suggests that even in the classroom setting, oral and aural experiences played a crucial role in womens self-making process, in addition to reading and writing. Our second paper examines visual representations that pertained to post-1949 literacy campaigns in China. Images of women teaching and learning, which circulated as propaganda posters, contributed to the redefinition of aesthetic tastes and womens virtue in socialist China. Our third paper questions the power of literacy from a bodily perspective by uncovering the dynamic social choreography of the mass dance movement from 1958 to 1960. Through a cinematic lens, our last paper concludes this panel by examining how a female director used multimedia approaches to express herself and explore the politics of space and its relationship to the representation of women in post-1978 China within the context of globalization.

session-title: New Directions in Research on Policy Making in China
text: Research on policy making in China has grown, particularly since the turn of the 21st century. As a result, we now know more about the role bureaucratic actors in designing and formulating policy, as well as the increased influence of non-state actors in some policy spheres and their ability to get ideas on the policy agenda. Our panel further advances understanding by introducing new methods, data and conceptual frameworks that together show the possibilities for a more dynamic understanding of policy making, elite policy coordination, and the limited impacts of new, more inclusive policy agendas. Duckett incorporates dynamic network analysis into an examination of how health policy ideas and networks have evolved over time. Huhe and Stepan analyse a large dataset on leading small groups (LSGs) to explore intra-elite networks and coordinating mechanisms. Zhu, Xiao and Ding explore improved portrayals of marginalised groups in policy and media circles and the obstacles to translating them into meaningful programmatic change. Together the papers form a panel that opens up new directions in research on policy making in China - directions that are better able to show evolving policy networks and endogenous policy change, track interactions among elite policy makers and coordination and across policy areas; and show the obstacles to meaningful social policy implementation.

session-title: Overturning Old Ideas About Yuan Architecture
text: The four papers of this panel explore how longstanding ideas about Yuan architecture, and thereby China under Mongol rule, can be overturned by 21st century discoveries, methodologies, and perspectives. The first two papers examine Yuan tombs that have become known in recent years. Steinhardt argues that despite the burial goods that point to a Chinese tomb occupant, the brick, dome-on-square structure and location identify a tomb as Muslim and for Yuan-period royalty. With a focus on actual burial structure and painted or carved building motifs, Lins paper reconsiders how a presumably enclosed and cohesive burial space was deconstructed in the Yuan period, and he then explains what a different conception of tombs the new construction reveals. Zuo turns to anthropological studies of contemporary vernacular timber architecture and exposes a technological regression that existed in Yuan architecture due, she argues, to social and economic causes. Yu investigates Xia Yong, a painter who takes architecture as his subjects and turns buildings into two-dimensional representations, to show how a Yuan artist redefined Song-period representations of architecture. This panel intentionally chooses four kinds of architecture the brick structure, underground burial, timber-frame structure, and representations on silk to explore the topic in the widest possible way. By challenging generally accepted views of these four manifestations of Yuan architecture, we seek to pose and suggest answers for questions about art, architecture and craftsmanship during the Yuan dynasty.

session-title: Data Past, Data Present: Chinese Narratives Of/as Information History
text: From the digitization of collections, to the development of computational tools for document markup and statistical analysis, new forms of data-centered research are expanding the ways in which scholars engage with texts. Crucial to the rise of the so-called digital humanities is the task of datafication the extraction of morselized information from a document and its aggregation into larger sets a process that underlies empirical analysis and visual summary, producing not only new historical and literary knowledge but even new ways of knowing altogether. This panel seeks to both showcase and historicize data in China studies in order to explore the intersections between the datafication of the past and the past of datafication: What can late imperial bureaucratic conventions of embedding citational data tell us about the formal tensions between linear narrative and nonlinear dataframe (Wang)? When did textual datafication become a historiographic tool, and how did it produce accounts of its own technologies and impulses (Detwyler)? What is the more recent history of computational humanities in China, and what are its connections to and differences with the rise of digital humanities in the West (Chen)? How can digitized corpora help us identify patterns in premodern textual practices of citation itself a latent form of data management in Chinese writing (Sturgeon)? Ranging from the pre-Qin to the present, these diverse case studies collectively provide an opportunity to critically locate data as a subject and method within the study of Chinese history.

session-title: History and Memory in the PRC: Competing Narratives of the Anti-Rightist
text: Writing memoirs of the Maoist era can be a challenge to the Chinese state control of historical narratives, especially with the increasing suppression of dissent under Xi Jinping. Nevertheless, those who wish to recall pasts diverging from the orthodox have remained resilient and innovative in their efforts. How should we understand these beneath the radar works? This panel, taking the Anti-Rightist Campaign of 1957-58 as a case study, discusses four facets of this interplay between history and memory. We present narratives from across the ideological spectrum that compete not only against the state, but with each other. Though memory is self-serving and therefore unreliable in restoring history, we explore memoirs as a discourse and for the positions taken by their writers. Dayton Lekner traces the ongoing struggle between Party loyalists and those labeled Rightist for appropriation and control of the key imagery, and associated memories, of the campaign. Yidi Wu explores changing perceptions of the label Rightist itself - from being marginalized and punished to taking pride and becoming dissidents. William Sima explores the biographies of three victims of the campaign as both a way of challenging Party lore and ideology, and as problematic in their return to the tradition of biography as history. Last, Anja Blanke investigates the interplay of competing narratives among memoirs written by survivors of the campaign. Overall, our panel contributes to a better understanding of the corpus of unofficial writing surrounding the Anti-Rightist Campaign and asks what place history, and historiography, might afford these works.

session-title: Advances in Understanding Chinese Court Behavior
text: New Supreme Peoples Court (SPC) rules which took effect in the beginning of 2014 requiring every court at every level to publish every decision online (with some exceptions, and as part of broader online government transparency initiatives) introduce the tantalizing possibility of revolutionizing the study of Chinese court behavior. At the present time, almost everything we know about Chinese courts comes from the qualitative analysis of interview and ethnographic data and the quantitative analysis of small samples of manually coded court decisions. The public accessibility of tens of millions of written court decisions necessitates radically different strategies of data collection, management, and analysis. The papers in this panel represent path-breaking efforts to chart this new research frontier by showcasing innovative analytical techniques, fresh empirical findings, and cautionary lessons about data bias. The papers in this panel also collectively embody the ideals of diversity championed by the AAS in terms of discipline, rank, gender, ethnicity, nationality, and methodology. Liebmans paper, drawing on over one million court decisions from Henan Province, is intended as a primer on the use and misuse of online court decisions. Michelsons analysis of the same court decisions from Henan reveals discrimination against women on a massive scale in the context of divorce litigation. Lis paper, also on divorce litigation, reveals the nature and extent of important discrepancies between the language of courts in action and the language of published decisions. Finally, Smith tackles the issue of bias in the selective publication of SPC death penalty review decisions.

session-title: China and the World in 1900: Comparative Perspectives
text: 1900 was a dramatic year for China, due to such events as the the fifty-five day siege of Beijing laid by anti-Christian militants known as Boxers and Qing Dynasty troops, and the international invasion by an Allied Army with soldiers from eight countries.  This panel will ask how new light can be shed on these actions by paying attention to comparisons, some of which move across space, others across time.  In 1900, many participants and observers thought of Chinese events as related to or entwined with conflicts underway in other places (e.g., the Tagalog Rebellion), and there was much talk as well about echoes of the past (e.g., Britons often likened the siege of Beijing to one that took place during the 1857 Mutiny).  After 1900, moreover, analogies have been drawn between the Boxers and other groups, including the Red Guards.  Each participant in this panel will bring up comparisons that move between countries, periods, or both.  The format will be innovative in that the panel will be divided into three parts.  In the first, geographical comparisons will be central.  Xu will give a short presentation that moves between China and the United States and Sebring will give one on contrasting visual works produced in Asia and the West in 1900.  After their presentations both no more than ten minutes there will be twenty minutes for discussion among all panelists and give and take with the audience. The second third will concentrate on chronological comparisons, with Wasserstrom exploring ways that the Chinese crisis could generate a sense of deja  vu, while Bickers looks at later events that can be seen as replays of sorts of things that happened in 1900.  Again, the presentations will be short, the time for discussion extended.  The final third will have no presentations just discussion.  To start it, though, Meyer-Fong, a specialist in earlier periods, and Mitter, who has worked most on World War II, will give short comments that reflect on the comparisons raised up to that point and perhaps suggest further ones.

session-title: Approaches to Economic Reconstruction in China, 1930s-1950s
text: The three decades of the 1930s-1950s were a time of intensive change in China, as the Japanese invasion was followed by the civil war and the Communist victory in 1949.  War and political transitions serve as conventional boundaries of historical periodization, but such boundaries can be interrogated and challenged by identifying the underlying structures and continuous views that run through them.  Focusing on industrial organizations, this panel investigates approaches to economic reconstruction dating from the pre-war or wartime periods that persisted through the tumultuous years that followed.  The panel presents three types of industrial organization: low-level local industrial cooperatives, a leading shipping company with a national reach, and the largest state-owned manufacturer of iron and steel.  All three originated in the pre-war or wartime period and navigated the political transitions of the postwar in pursuit of their visions of a stable and independent China.  Together, these archive-based studies argue for the resilience and continuity of economic ideas, management models, and above all, shared priorities for reconstruction that emerged from the wartime period and appealed across the political spectrum in subsequent years.

session-title: Law in Early Imperial China: Interpretation and Transformation
text: The discovery of thousands of legal and administrative manuscripts, along with careful re-readings of transmitted texts, has allowed scholars to reconstruct the legal institutions of Chinas early imperial period (221 BCE-220 CE) in unprecedented detail. As all students of early Chinese law readily admit, however, recovered statutes and ordinances themselves tell us little about legal praxis. The study of legal interpretation has thus largely been confined to high-level decisions and the use of the Classics in Han jurisprudence. Correspondingly, it can be difficult to set aside statist assumptions of law as a strategy of social control when we focus on areas beyond the most elite levels of the imperial court. This panel attempts to do precisely that, however, by asking two questions: 1) How does our picture of early imperial law change when we assume that laws were not just instruments of control but also sites for interpretation? 2) How was legal meaning transformed as statutes, edicts, problematic cases, precedents, and petitions were transmitted across social and spatial divisions? Each panelist will address these questions through analysis of sources that reflect the dynamics of legal interpretation and transformation at distinct social levels and geographic areas, from local counties and commanderies to regional kingdoms to the imperial court. Rather than the traditional format of successive presentations, the chair will discuss larger trends in the field of early legal history, followed by shortened and collaborative presentations of key findings, concluding with a response from the discussant designed to elicit wider audience participation.

session-title: Reconfiguring the Past: Religio-Philosophical Inquiry in Modern Chinese Literature
text: This panel integrates historical, literary, religious and philosophical inquiry to examine how modern and contemporary Chinese intellectuals interweave a wide spectrum of Eastern and Western religio-philosophical traditions into their creative writing and translation. As scholarly consensus has it, the introduction of Western intellectual history into China in the twentieth century provided an impetus towards ideological modernization; in this process of self-rejuvenation, the dialectical relationship between Western culture and Asian tradition compelled Chinese intellectuals to reconfigure their cultural legacy while appropriating Western thought. Drawing into discussion several religio-philosophical traditions (specifically wu-shamanism, Tibetan Buddhism, Zen Buddhism, Taoism, and Christianity), this panel takes a comparative perspective on four key episodes, spanning the period from the late Qing era to the contemporary period, in which writers linked Chinese and Western literature and religion/philosophy. Shuyang Pan examines the reconstruction of literary wu-shamanism by two Chinese writers, Xiao Hong (1911-1942) and Duanmu Hongliang (1912-1996), as they confront the conflict between the primitive and the modern. Xiaolu Ma explores the early twentieth century Chinese transculturation and secularization of Tolstoyism, with its deep roots in Russian Orthodox Christianity and Asian Taoism and Buddhism. Jianmei Liu interrogates the connection between the Zen Buddhist comprehension of Dao and the representation of women in Nobel laureate Gao Xingjians novels and plays. Finally, Thomas Moran investigates the intersection of Western philosophy and Tibetan Buddhism in a study of the representation of human consciousness in Ning Kens 2010 novel Tian Â· Zang.

session-title: An Archeology of the Popular: Renegotiating Language, Point of View, and Authority
text: Profound shifts in the popularity and status of drama as well as the literary uses of vernacular language, fictional portrayal, and humor have garnered much attention in recent studies of late imperial Chinese theater (1550-1911).  Less well understood are the roots of these transformations in works from earlier periods.  Centering on readings of discourses associated with theater and song during middle period China (1115-1550), this panel explores the expanding use of colloquial language and the embrace of a broader social range of figures such as actors, peasants, and diasporic authors in writings from the Yuan and Ming. The papers seek to engage with the following questions: Do these works reflect a spoken language of any sort, or are they inventing a new literary standard that makes use of colloquial elements? Do they introduce new points of view only to dismiss them as comic fodder for a literary elite or do they empower outsiders? Do the new forms of humor reinforce the existing literary socio-hierarchies, or do they challenge cultural authority? Is the meaning of acting on stage a form of didactic suasion, an incantatory and illusionistic invocation of historical paragons, and/or a platform for the virtuoso display of vocal, verbal, and comic skills?  Taken together, the papers in this panel reveal how shifting language registers, points of view, and a new found authority of humor challenged conventional standards of literary expression, thus paving the way for new literati norms and attitudes vis-a-vis performance-related forms in the late Ming.

session-title: Two-part Panel:Knowledge Production, Reading Practice, and Meaning Making in
text: During the first two decades of the Peoples Republic, publishing companies, cultural agencies, and party organs adopted and adapted the productive technologies and organizational systems of the prior capitalist publishing system to serve the needs of state socialism. This panel explores previously unexamined dynamics of socialist cultural production during the Mao era to complicate our understanding of that process. Lius and Culps papers focus on how new agents of production, respectively the Womens Federation and a consortium of publishing companies under the Ministry of Culture, generated new periodicals and series publications. In turn, Lu and Yang concentrate on very material processes of book production by illuminating how paper was supplied to print Maos Little Red Book and the resurgent technology of archaic woodblock printing was used to make books for connoisseurs. In combination, the papers demonstrate the diverse ways cultural producers appropriated existing technologies and organizational systems, or invented new ones, to express their messages. These various agents and approaches to textual production developed even as the Chinese Communist Party sought to centralize control of the publishing industry in unprecedented ways. Yet the papers also suggest how genres of text ranging from journals, classics, and series to the Little Red Book were subject to party governance even as they contributed to its development in various ways. For both of these coordinated panels, the chairs will provide brief framing comments. For panel I, the chair and discussant will each comment for ten minutes at the end of the paper presentations.

session-title: Manufacturing the Metropolis in Modern and Contemporary China
text: Chinas metropolitan areas have experienced phenomenal growth in recent decades. This panel examines how industries reshaped socio-spatial dimensions of mega-cities in modern and contemporary China. Moving beyond the modernization versus local identity paradigm, the four case studies in Tianjin, Shanghai, Daqing, and Chongqing identify institutional changes that stimulated urban expansion. These mega-cities underwent cycles of fragmentation and consolidation. The power struggle between Chinese railway developers and foreign river conservancy bureaus devolved into a turf war that led to Tianjins expansion. Catastrophes created openings for the centralization of urban planning. The 1917 flood which damaged the Tianjin railway station forced Chinese and foreigners to collaborate and avert future disasters; The 1950 air raid in Shanghai prompted the local electrical power bureau to micro-manage power consumption of hundreds of factories. State policy had to be adapted to fit local realities. Oil workers of Daqing in the 1960s lived in decentralized settlements made of mud houses similar to those of local peasants. This was in line with state policy of social equality and also led to urban-rural integration. More recently, deindustrialization turns out to be the driving force for urban expansion. State-owned heavy industries in Chongqing have branched out to other industries and moved from the urban core into the periphery. Coordination between state and local authorities, careful rationing of resources, urban-rural integration, narratives of progress through memory-making, lay the groundwork for a model of high-density urban development unique to China.

session-title: Voices from the Sea: Fishers, Territorial Waters and  Ocean Culture
text: In popular discourses, territories are often used to refer to lands. Little attention is paid to open waters and the people who spend time in them. This panel uses ocean/ sea as a central theme to examine how human activities in the waters complicate state policies, jurisdictional boundaries and the identities of the people working in the sea. A closer examination of open waters also sheds new light on the center/ periphery binary in national geography because while oceans and seas may be distant from administrative centers, many also serve as important contact zones between nations or regions. Xiaofei Gaos paper explores the fishery industries in coastal villages in southern Northeast China from the late 1940s to the Mao era, explicating how laborers in the sea destabilized conventional land-oriented class labels of workers and peasants. The work and earnings of fishermen disrupted the states campaign in creating equality among the rural population. Angelina Chins paper also focuses on the fisheries, but shifts the geographical focus to the sea border separating the mainland and colonial Hong Kong. The floating bodies and kidnapping cases on the coast of Lau Fau Shan give new geographical meanings to the Cultural Revolution. Tabitha Mallorys paper returns to the contemporary period and analyzes the ocean strategies as China emerged as a global maritime power. Along with the increasing state involvement were the efforts in creating a narrative portraying China as an "ocean country" and the development of an ocean culture to help people understand ocean affairs.

session-title: New Approaches in Chinese Environmental History:  Transregional and Frontier
text: This panel draws on the latest approaches in environmental history to explore the ways in which interactions between humans and their environments can help in reevaluating questions of territorial space, national sovereignty, and resource exploitation particularly for frontiers and borderlands in East Asia. Over the last two centuries, frontier regions not only experienced significant environmental change but also played important roles in the construction of national discourses surrounding both the meaning of nature and the execution of state-building projects. As frontier studies have occupied a central place in the environmental history of the United States, this panel examines the relevance of such an approach to China. Jonathan Schlesingers study traces transregional ecological transformations through resource consumption to reach conclusions regarding scale and boundary in Asian environmental history. Shifting this line of inquiry to local examples of resource protection, Tristan Browns paper examines legal cases that highlight the cultural strategies invoked in local courts along the Qings southwestern frontier for the maintenance of common resources and environments. Shellen Wus paper explores the role of Chinese frontiers in Republican-era discourses of national development and demonstrates how these discussions continue to inform questions of sovereignty today. In a similar vein, Micah Muscolinos paper examines efforts in water and soil conservation in northwestern China during the Second Sino-Japanese War and investigates their long-term legacies. In sum, this panel documents new approaches in Chinese environmental history by centering frontier spaces and aims to encourage discussion about the potential contributions of frontier studies to Chinese environmental history.

session-title: Beyond Digitization, Cross-Specialization
text: Beyond Digitization, Cross-Specialization  Scholarship and librarianship are inextricably linked in this digital era. The volume of information available electronically may bewilder seasoned scholars. Meanwhile, shifting expectations for academic libraries may intimidate veteran librarians. Increased information access offers exciting opportunities for scholar-librarian cooperation, but complicates the traditional scholar-librarian relationship. The AAS conference provides a unique opportunity for scholars and librarians to come together, and we propose our panel as a chance for honest dialogue about scholars and librarians ambitions and concerns regarding digital scholarship. Three scholar-librarian pairs will discuss three recent collaborations across specializations. Zhaohui Xue and Yan Long discuss establishing a web archive of online content created by grassroots Chinese NGOs - a project whose politically-sensitive nature might have deemed it impossible without library support and faculty interest. Responding to the proliferation of databases for studying historical China, Feng En-tu and Lik Hang Tsui argue that academic libraries must train scholars in digital methodologies, and assert the need for discipline-specific software applications, data collections, and standards. Cecile Sun turns a critical eye toward digital humanities, questioning quantitative researchs value to the discipline. With Tianni Wang, she describes an oral history project that has convinced her of digital humanities potential and the possibilities for librarian-faculty cooperation. Discussants Peter Bol and Jim Cheng will facilitate conversation about the intersection of scholarship, instruction, and information management.

session-title: Medicine, Material Culture, and Daily Life in Middle Period China
text: Our roundtable examines the intersection of medicine, market, and material culture in Middle Period China. Rapid developments in Song era markets deeply impacted cultures of health, most obviously in the price, circulation, and knowledge of drug materials. Drug prices played a role in the popular perceptions of efficacy. New forms of medical knowledge influenced the Song states attempt to monopolize the import of medicinals, such as luxury aromatics from the Indian Ocean. Local drug markets merged with temple fairs, and the marketplace became an integral part of local healing practice. Meanwhile, physicians and literati variously embraced and pointedly rejected the norms of the marketplace, seeking health in the materiality of everyday life, rustic foods, and easy-to-get drug materials. How did professional physicians and amateurs respond to market factors and the changing conditions of daily lives? How does our attention to material culture illuminate medicine and healing culture during the Song and the Song-Yuan-Ming transition? What does our attention to the materiality of healing cultures illuminate about Chinas Middle Period? Each panelist will use a case study to discuss these questions. Margaret Ng examines the increasing use of frankincense in medicine for women in relation to state monopoly of imports. Hsiao-wen Cheng studies the Song differentiation between the two kinds of zhu (atractylodes rhizome)--cangzhu and baizhu--and the new attention drawn to the former. TJ Hinrichs explores thirteenth century valorizations of rustic foods and lifestyles as means to health, focusing on Lin Hongs Pure Offerings of Mountain Dwellers(Shanjia qinggong) and Pure Matters of Mountain Dwellers (Shanjia qingshi). Kai-hsiang Hsu investigates the development of a drug market in front of a Daoist temple, Yuju Guan, in Chengdu. Brigid Vance analyzes the recipes and advice for promoting healthy sleep and dreaming from the Song to the Ming included in An Explication of the Profundities in the Forest of Dreams (Menglin xuanjie). We will precirculate our materials to all those committed to attending the panel. Each panelist will present ten minutes only, leaving ample time for discussion.

session-title: Governing Society in Contemporary China and Taiwan
text: This panel focuses on the nexus of political authorities, laws, and social actors in contemporary China and Taiwan to explore how these states govern society.  Taking a multidisciplinary approach, it examines both how government officials engage with social actors and the implications for state-society relations.   Legal anthropology scholar Anya Bernstein analyzes how administrative law in Taiwan is shaped and interpreted by public law court judges and administrators.  Law and politics researcher Margaret Boittin highlights the ground-level tensions that play out between local level policing and health bureaucrats whose policies towards sex workers conflict with one another.  Management and politics professor Greg Distelhorst studies the biases of local officials when listening to ordinary citizens.  Political scientist Diana Fu examines Chinas new feminist movement and explains why the state has targeted it for repression. All four papers present new evidence on the points of contact between political authorities and ordinary citizens in China and Taiwan.  They also share common themes, with a focus on gender (Boittin and Fu), judicial and public security agencies (Bernstein, Boittin, Distelhorst, and Fu), and the behavior of local officials (Bernstein, Boittin, and Distelhorst).  The studies are also methodologically diverse, drawing on survey, interview, and ethnographic research methods.  Senior scholar Mary Gallagher, an expert on law, politics, and state-society relations in China, will discuss the papers in the context of the topical and theoretical themes.

session-title: Of Rules and Men - the Qing Imperial Institutions and Their Legal Framework
text: From the earliest records available, institutions of government have developed in close interaction with the law. Turning their attention away from previously favored interpretations of the role of law in history, in recent decades, scholars of Chinas imperial regime have shed light on the extent to which the operation of its institutions was intricately linked to the dynamics of society and to the existence of a rich and evolving legal tradition. Benefitting from the existence of rich and abundant archival sources, central as well as local, Chinas late imperial period has been at the forefront of this innovative research, allowing for an ever-finer perception of the specific workings of the legislative machinery in its relation to the various components of the state and society. The four papers grouped in this panel jointly address the issue of the role of the law in framing the multidimensional workings of Qing dynasty institutions, from the perspective of central and territorial institutions. Each presenter will shed light on a specific facet of the question by combining an analysis of actual judicial cases, of legislation and its evolution, and of the different stages and actors of the judicial procedure. In combination, these contributions will provide the grounds for a renewed discussion of how exactly legal principles infused the ordinary workings of the Qings bureaucratic monarchy and on the intricate interrelation between the bureaucracy and society in the shaping of this process.

session-title: Stalin and China: Mining the Archives and Shedding New Light
text: In this panel, four scholars who have done extensive archival research in Russia and elsewhere address the important historical role played by Stalin in China from the late 1920s to the mid-1950s.  Four case studies on a range of topics shed new light on the great extent of Stalins influence on China, as well as its limits. Hua-yu Lis paper examines how Chinese students sent to Moscow in the mid- to late-1920s learned how to purge political adversaries through their own experiences in the midst of the brutal purges carried out during Stalins Cultural Revolution between 1928-1931. Alexander V. Pantsovs study explores the double game played by Chiang Kai-shek and Stalin as they competed to impose their respective visions on the relationship between China and the USSR. Deborah Kaple examines radically different reactions to Khrushchevs February 1956 denunciation of Stalin in the Soviet Union and China. Soviet citizens accepted the facts about Stalins crimes as presented by Khrushchev, but Chinese citizens reacted with shock and could not accept the Soviet condemnation of Stalin. Koji Hirata analyzes the reconstruction and expansion of the Anshan Steel and Iron Works (Angang), one of the 156 central projects of Chinas first Five-Year Plan (1953-57), launched with aid from Stalin. Even in this era of learning from Stalins Soviet Union, the Sino-Soviet relationship at the local level was characterized by tension, miscommunication, and miscalculations.

session-title: Disasters and the Reimagining of Modern China
text: Far from externalities disrupting normal life, disasters and disaster planning became constitutive elements of modern Chinas social organization and historical imagination. Yet studies have only begun to grapple with this fact. Depending on the particular circumstances in which disasters occurred or were expected to occur, Chinese leaders, scientists, and bureaucrats used different frames to mediate the meanings of disaster and in the process produced new subjectivities and ways of knowing and organizing society and the world. Using insights from cultural history, environmental history, and science and technology studies, this panel examines three understudied disasters (earthquakes, wartime bombing, and typhoons) at extraordinary junctures in Chinese history (late Qing national humiliation, the threat of Chinas demise in WWII, and mass mobilization under Mao) to examine how they were appropriated to refashion notions of history, nation, and community, and effect social change.  Daniel Hausmann looks at how the introduction of the earthquake table fissured dynastic notions of time and buttressed a national history of suffering in the early Republic. John B. Thompson examines how unpredictable destruction by Japanese bombs in World War II Chongqing led planners to a new technocratic view of Chinese society as a network of crucial industrial and social functions arranged in physical space. As Clark Alejandrino shows, modern meteorology and mass mobilization in 1950s Guangdong transformed local organizations and understandings against typhoons while legitimizing Communist rule.  Judith Shapiro and Grace Shen, who have worked on the history of Chinese disasters and science, are discussant and chair respectively.

session-title: Sensory Pleasures and Perils in Premodern China
text: Confucius said that he had never met anyone who loved virtue (de) as much as sensual pleasure (se), tacitly admitting that virtue and pleasure are not easily dissociated. Ever since, the pleasures of the senses have been fraught with profound moral and political ramifications in Chinese cultural tradition. Drawing on the insights of previous scholarship by Ronald Egan, Craig Clunas, Jonathan Hay, and others, our panel sheds new light on the cultural meaning of sensory pleasures. How were the pleasures of the senses--whether tactile, olfactory, gustatory, visual, or auditory--both regulated and also defined by political concerns, and how could cultural norms and ideals be represented materially? We examine the representation of sensory experience in various literary genres from different periods of imperial China, using both interdisciplinary readings of received texts and also newly discovered or overlooked materials. David Knechtges examines the early discourse of the perils of immoderation via a newly discovered Han manuscript, but Hsiang-lin Shih shows how the allure of swords and feminine beauty were used for political ends in the early medieval period. Nicholas M. Williams analyzes the allegorical implications of floral fragrances in Southern Song ci lyrics, while Guojun Wang unveils the materiality of genres via a close study of clothing in the writings of Kong Shangren. By restoring the broader cultural contexts of tangible and mundane experience, our papers offer initial forays toward a history of both the pleasures and perils of the senses in premodern China.

session-title: The Extension of Credit in Modern Chinese History
text: This panel brings together historians, economists, and political scientists who use different approaches and methodologies to study the extension of credit in Chinese history. Qiao examines how Shanxi merchants, through credit-extension and account balancing, created new transactional practices on the northern frontier of the Qing Empire where precious metal was in short supply. Deans paper examines why a consortium of foreign banks was willing to lend money to the Qing, and then the Beiyang government, for currency reform. The paper by Manconi provides new insights on the effects of the infamous Silver Purchase Act of 1934 by conducting an econometric analysis on the records of a Tianjin bank. Finally, Chen investigates the capital structure and loan portfolio of the China Development Bank in the present day to show the relation between political and economic goals. Taken together, these papers examine the economic, political, diplomatic, and personal factors that influence the extension of credit. At a broader level, the panel aims to increase interdisciplinary communication by providing a forum to share perspectives, tools, and approaches.

session-title: Zhao Ziyangs Legacy: A Reassessment
text: When Chinas deposed former leader Zhao Ziyang died under house arrest in 2005, his 59-character-long official obituary was notable primarily for its omissions: referring to Zhao only as a comrade, it did not mention that he had served as General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party (1987-1989), Premier of the State Council (1980-1987), or Party Secretary of Sichuan Province (1975-1980). Zhao who was at the pinnacle of Chinese politics for nearly a decade from 1980-1989 has been erased from most official Chinese accounts of the period, and scholarship about Zhao has long been limited by a lack of access to essential source material. Recently, however, scholars have benefitted from a wide range of major new insights, sources, and arguments regarding Zhaos contributions and these new sources have led to a reevaluation of Zhaos contested legacy. This roundtable will reassess Zhao Ziyang by examining five interrelated topics: (1) Zhaos overall legacy as an economic and political reformer and national leader; (2) Zhaos workstyle and policy orientations; (3) his interactions with other CCP elites (including Hu Yaobang and Deng Xiaoping) that led ultimately to his overthrow in 1989; (4) Zhaos role in Chinas foreign relations, notably U.S.-China relations; and (5) how the understanding of Zhaos legacy has been altered by the appearance of newly available materials. Professor David Shambaugh, who published the first biography of Zhao in 1984, will chair and direct the panel, while also addressing the first issue. Professor Wu Guoguang, a former official who worked under and closely with Zhao will discuss the second issue. Robert Suettinger, former senior CIA analyst and NSC Director for Asia under President Clinton, closely followed Chinese domestic politics in the 1980s and will speak about the third issue. Former U.S. Ambassador to China Winston Lord interacted directly with Zhao and observed him in his government capacity, will discuss the fourth issue. Julian Gewirtz, who has recently published a book examining Zhaos economic reforms and their international interconnections, will discuss the fifth issue. All participants will address the fundamental question of what Zhao Ziyangs legacy means for contemporary Chinese history, for the study of Chinese politics, and for Chinas future.

session-title: New Perspectives on Migration in Chinese History
text: In all eras, people, goods, and ideas traveled into, across, and out of what is now China. Recent years have seen a rising interest in the study of migration in contemporary China, yet migration in the imperial period remains an under-researched topic. This panel focuses on the political, economic, social contexts of human mobility in China through case studies from various historical periods. In the light of recently excavated sources from the Qin and early Western Han periods, Korolkov investigates the role of state control over mobile populations in the formation of early Chinese empires. Settlers are usually presented as colonizers and agents of the empire, yet, as Tsai shows, settlers often adapted to the place they settled. He shows this through a comparison of how the Qing and Russian Empires perceived and reacted to the nativization of their settlers in Central Eurasia. Huangs paper turns attention from migrants to the left-behind families. By analyzing cases of ransom and cross-border transportation of the deceased during the Northern Wei and Southern Dynasties, she reveals how migration shifted boundaries of home and family. In contrast to the above three papers that focus on separation and dislocation, Ebrey argues that frequent large-scale migration, even when involuntary, in time helped make possible Chinas repeated unifications by bringing people of different localities, languages, and customs together.

session-title: Canton, Beijing, and the Court: Chinese Export Painting Revisited
text: So-called Chinese export paintings usually refer to paintings from the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries made by annoymous artisans in Canton for a Euro-Amercian market. These paintings are often seen as mass produced souvenirs and as such, treated as works with little aesthetic values, and therefore relegated to the margins of art history as an isolated genre of study. Consequently, very little attention has been paid to their connection with mainstream Chinese art and the significance of local production in the making of art for a foreign audience. This panel intends to shed new light on the subject of export art by examining the court-city-port production network of an eighteenth century China. There are four papers covering export art productions in Canton and Beijing, their relationship with Chinese material culture, court workshop pratice, and finally their post-China biographies in Europe. By expanding the geographical scope to include the inland, these papers will shift from the China/West narrative that has long dominated the field of export art. It will also expand the West to include export artworks in Russian collections, adding another node in the network of commerical art in Qing China. It endeavors to show how export paintings were not merely the product of foreign fantasy or the monopoly of the coastal cities but enjoyed a reciprocal interaction with traditional Chinese art practices and has played a significant role in shaping an understanding of China. Therefore, they are an indispensable link to understanding later Chinese art from a global perspective.

session-title: Two-part Panel: Knowledge Production, Reading Practice, and Meaning Making in
text: As books, journals, comics, pamphlets and big character posters were produced in diverse ways for new purposes during the Mao era, who read them, and more importantly,  how did they read them? For reading was a fraught and contested process during the early PRC, as intellectuals and academic work came under intense scrutiny, mass literacy and education campaigns created new reading communities, and collective reading became a fundamental feature of political study processes. These papers demonstrate how the CCP sought to use mediated reading practices to extend its governmental reach to shape communities and individuals throughout the Mao era. Focusing on the early PRC, DeMare explores how urban intellectuals interpretations of party policies and revolutionary narratives determined the dynamics of land reform in local communities. Sun illuminates the imposition of state censorship on personal reading during the Cultural Revolution and its limitations. Despite these efforts, however, Henningsen and Mittler suggest that there were continuities in reading practices and forms of meaning from before and after the Cultural Revolution, and indicate ways that readers were often creative participants in the process of meaning making, forming communities of reading whose importance might go far beyond the process of readerly and writerly engagement. Together, these panels map the entire communications circuit (Darnton) for Maoist China from the conception and planning of texts to their material production and circulation to readers consumption and reaction and link it to broader dynamics of state building and governmentality.

session-title: Big Data Analysis of Chinese Religions on Social Media Under Xi Jinping Regime
text: Any scholar in the humanities and social science who studies China would face a dilemma about original data. On the one hand, accesses to archival documents, to elite individuals, and to social surveys are often restricted and the obstacles are too difficult to overcome. On the other hand, the wealth of available data is beyond any individuals capability to digest in a lifetime. What makes the task all the more daunting is the datas variety, which ranges from historical gazetteers and maps to the news, images, and social media posts of our time. This unprecedented volume of information can, however, also be considered a sealed treasure trove that, once opened, has the potential to illuminate past and present in ways hitherto thought closed for lack of practical methods to give the findings shape and meaning.         The panels purpose is to present some of these methods and see how they can be brought to bear on society, politics, or religion in China. Since computational methods cover a wide range and include spatial, temporal, network, and textual analysis, as well as techniques of graphic, cartographic, and virtual visualization, scholars of different disciplinary background, endowed with different expertise, should feel at home participating.  We hope is that the mutual stimulation that results will initiate a new computational approach to the understanding of China. We will particularly focus on big data analysis of social media about religions posted since 2012.

session-title: East Asian International Relations in the Trump Era
text: This panel brings together a group of political scientists with expertise in Northeast Asian international relations to answer pressing questions concerning the regions contemporary politics. The papers have broad geographical coverage: US-China relations, Japan-South Korea-US relations, China-South Korea-US relations, and Chinese domestic politics and foreign policy. Their research questions tackle pressing issues of theoretical and policy concern, including: 1) why does China increasingly employ coercive diplomacy toward South Korea, pressuring Seoul to abandon a US missile defense system despite an objectively worsening threat from North Korea? 2) What are the prospects for domestic politics to allow for improved Japan-South Korea relations in this rapidly changing threat environment? 3) Why is Chinas rise to great power status in the 21st century different from those of the past, and what does that mean for the applicability of existing theories to this contemporary case? And 4) during a period in which both Chinas material capabilities/influence and concerns about U.S. commitment to global leadership are increasing, what determines how Chinese leaders conceptualize leadership and how likely they are to pursue such a role internationally?

session-title: Postcolonial Identity Politics in Hong Kong
text: The salience and radicalization of identity politics in Hong Kong is one of the most unprecedented and unexpected changes since the end of Britishcolonial rule. Despite Chinas economic enticements and intense efforts to promote patriotism, a variety of localist identities and movements have flourished in Hong Kong among a younger generation, with some activists making the once unthinkable claim for political independence.  How does one analytically define Hong Kong and Hong Konger? This panel examines the multiple and contradictory trajectories of identity politics and value change in Hong Kong in the past two decades and especially after the Umbrella Movement laid bare the governments forceful means to exert political control and revealed its determination to redefine the One Country Two Systems formula. The first paper uses aggregate longitudinal data to document the publics growing sense of political efficacy even as they register declining confidence in formal political institutions.  Another paper reinforces the panels focus on the evolution of diverse political identities as social movements and political regime become increasingly contentious.  Zeroing in on the spectrum of localist politics and identities, a third paper highlights the drastically changed relationship between a region and a political center.  The final paper uses the transmission of Hong Kongs collective memory towards June 4th 1989 to trace how a young generation of Hong Kong citizens gain diverse moral sensibilities and rapidly reposition themselves in face of a China that had turned from a nuanced cultural formation to an uncompromising political authority.

session-title: Healing Is a Many-Splendored Thing: Re-framing Interdisciplinary Relations and
text: The interdisciplinary implications of traditional Asian medicine and the rising popular enthusiasm for alternative healing modalities call for more concerted interdisciplinary scholarly efforts to expand ongoing inquiries and open new frontiers. This panel integrates complementary approaches to examine interdisciplinary relations and narratives of traditional Chinese and Tibetan medicines and promote dialogues across the disciplines. Panel paper topics include a) a historical examination of the transformation of the perception of the medical body following Chinas 1913 anatomy law, b) a literary study problematizing the cultural-ethical values underlying Chinese medical and literary narratives about the practice of medicinal cannibalism; c) an interartistic study of the poetics of Chinese narrative medicine in the context of emotional health and healing; and d) an anthropological framing of cultural narratives about epidemics and epidemiology in medieval Tibet. A coherent theme overarching this panel is the re-framing of multi-faceted interdisciplinary relationship in traditional Chinese and Tibetan medicines. This re-framing offers valuable clues for understanding the evolution and diversity of Asian medical traditions while also problematizing Traditional Chinese Medicine as a unified system of medical orthodoxy. Another shared theme is the re-framing of interdisciplinary narratives about Asian medicine. Specifically, these narratives are historical, ethical, aesthetic, and spiritual, which encompass the medical body, the medicinal body, emotional hygiene, and epidemiology. Such narrative-framing, while identifying contributory factors for the survival and sustainability of traditional Asian medicine, helps to both critique and preserve these traditions. Furthermore, it sheds an interdisciplinary light on the representations of medicine in Asian intellectual traditions.

session-title: Indian Gods, Chinese Trigrams, and the Transmission and Assimilation of
text: As a poor cousin of both science and religion, a begrudged relative of ritual and play, divination persists in the margins of established traditions. Nevertheless, divinations often highly specific methods and its material culture recommend it as an excellent topic for larger studies of the transmission and assimilation of traditions across cultural and linguistic boundaries. This panel highlights such process through case studies of Chinese divination texts spanning three millennia. Two papers bring divergent areal and methodological perspectives to bear on a single text, a circa 9th-century Dunhuang manuscript called the Moxishouluoor Method of MaheÅ›vara. Constance Cooks paper applies Sinological methods to situate this tradition with respect to the deep Chinese past, drawing on 4th and 1st-century BCE divination texts. Brandon Dotsons paper adopts a comparative and material cultural perspective to place the same text in a tradition that traces back to India, and which was transmitted to Tibetans and Turks along the Silk Road. Kelsey Seymours paper explores a system of divination also associated with the Hindu deity MaheÅ›vara, assimilated by Chinese Buddhists during the Tang. Here a tantric master identifies with MaheÅ›vara and commands a spirit to speak through a child. Beverley McGuire brings to bear a religious studies approach by investigating a 17th-century commentary to the 6th-century Divination Sutra that discusses the place of divination in Buddhism vis-Ã -vis conventional and ultimate truths. Together, and through their intersections, these papers open a discussion of processes of transmission, assimilation, and religious appropriation of a given ritual technology.

session-title: Nature and Cities: Discovering the Transformed Urban Environment in China
text: Chinese metropolises, like cities elsewhere, rely on the consumption and harnessing of natural resources for survival. With successes and failures, engineering projects have not only transformed the urban environment, but also reshaped close, yet complex, relationships between the urban population and the environment. Engineering the environment has been essential to urban growth in China for centuries, though historical changes of the urban environment remained less noticeable in contrast with the excessive attention given to the outward prosperity of cities. Drawing on theories from environmental and ecological studies, the history of science and technology, cultural geography, and urban planning, this highly interdisciplinary panel explores the transformed urban environment in Hangzhou, Kaifeng, and Tianjin of imperial and modern China. All four papers emphasize the history of urban engineering and address interactions between humanity and nature in urban spaces. Chen explores the ecological changes taking place in the Northern Song Kaifeng with the massive inflow of nonnative animal and plant species into the citys numerous gardens and parks. Duans paper examines the Hangzhou municipal governments effort to regulate and urbanize West Lake through a balance between economic profit and ecological sustainability in the Song Dynasty. Wangs study focuses on water control projects in Tianjin and the changing riparian communities in the Qing dynasty. Hes research investigates the engineering programs near West Lake conducted by the communist state with particular attention to the unexpected ecological failure caused by algae bloom in the 1950s.
