session-title: Making Subjects Fit to Rule: Cultural Revolutions in Twentieth-Century China
text: A cultural revolution, Mao Zedong argued in 1940, was necessary to create New China. Revolutionary culture was consequential not because it reflected revolutionary politics and economy, but because it prepared the ideological ground for the establishment of a new society and a new state under the leadership of the Chinese Communist Party. Mao invested the Marxist concept of culture (wenhua) with voluntarism. Culture became a pedagogical and a political force in its own right, a means to measure and to mobilize national development. After 1949, the Party would use cultural revolutions to disseminate the Communist worldview, create proletarian literature and art, combat illiteracy, develop scientific knowledge, and radicalize social relations. The aim was to cultivate revolutionary citizens who were not just politically committed and emotionally connected to the Communist cause, but possessed the level of culture that socialist governance required. These revolutionary citizens would use weapon and word to realize the Partys shifting vision of Chinese modernity. This panel examines the concept and practice of cultural revolutions to demonstrate the dynamic, changing role of culture in Chinese Communist ideology and governance. Mark McConaghy explores the Partys effort to revolutionize culture in the 1930s and 1940s. Lara Kusnetzky analyzes the empowerment of the proletariat through the writing of factory history in 1958. Patricia Thornton shows that the cultivation of literate citizens was central to the revolutionary politics of the 1950s and 1960s. Fabio Lanza investigates the radical re-thinking of education and hence the democratization of culture in the 1970s.

session-title: Connecting the Empire: New Perspectives on Transport, Communication, and
text: The panel explores the Qing Empire (1644-1912) as a spatial-temporal construct and its empire-building as a project of producing and consolidating the physical space of empire. While Qing China has received much scholarly attention as an early modern empire, the technical aspect of its territorial expansion and management of its varied geography are still far from being thoroughly understood. This panel thus asks about the ways in which the empire connected and synchronized its vast territories and frontiers. Specifically, we focus on the transport, communication, and calendrical systems, which made possible military operations in frontiers, large-scale logistic arrangements, long-distance information transmission, all of which worked to hold the imperial realm together. We will examine strategies, technologies, and practices employed to develop and maintain an empire-wide and, in some cases, transregional network that facilitated information and material exchange between different places within and beyond the empire. Through case studies addressing multiple localities and stages of Qing History, we hope to contribute to the understanding of Qing by constructing a panoramic and chronological narrative of the evolvement of its circulation system. Papers explore high-Qing military logistics and communication in the trans-Himalayan region, late-Qing establishment of international telecommunication and tension with foreign entities, extension of the postal system into Mongolia and Tibet, and imperial control of the calendar and time in the context of Inner Asian expansion. Our discussant will contribute remarks based on his recent work on information system, military logistics, and the maintenance of empire in British India and Chinese contexts.

session-title: Spatial Statecraft: Urban Political Narratives in Late Imperial and Early Republican
text: Over the course of the late Imperial and early Republican eras, the state defined and controlled the key spaces of Beijing including its palaces, academies, temples, streets, walls, and borders. Rather than passive settings for the display of state power, these spaces were dynamic arenas in which the rulers shaped their identities and built the foundations of their rule. This interdisciplinary panel examines the ways in which architecture and authority intersected in Beijing from the Ming through the early Republic. Campbell investigates the major factors impacting the design of the imperial palaces in the Yongle reign and how they contributed to the construction of his imperial identity. Wu considers how two Qing emperors articulated a new imperial imagination in remaking Beijings Lama Temple in the eighteenth century. Barish discusses several buildings associated with imperial education, examining the relationship between architecture and changing knowledge regimes from the eighteenth to the twentieth centuries. Finally, Yu focuses on the Embassy District and the development of Changan Avenue in the late Qing and early Republican years, exploring the relationship between disruptions in the spatial order and challenges to state rule. Using a broad range of sources and methodologies, these papers propose new ways of reading urban spaces as sources of power in state-building in Beijing over a period of approximately five centuries.

session-title: Knowledge of Exotica: Writing the Other and Placing the Self in Early Modern
text: Knowledge about exotica was in constant motion in early modern China. This panel parses the discursive roles of exotica as textual objects in Chinese historiography and literature from the early seventeenth to late nineteenth centuries. We explore how a variety of men of letters adapted ideas of the foreign and the strange to respond, on the one hand, to social and political transformations, and reflect, on the other, upon their own cultural, political, and ethnic identities. The four papers draw on assorted materials antiquity catalogues, miscellaneous jottings, bannerman drama, and popular fiction to discuss how knowledge producers manipulated discourses of exotica to situate themselves and the empires they inhabited in relation to borderlands, foreign countries, and spiritual realms. Representations of exotic phenomena, such as tribute goods, imported weaponry, foreign languages and customs, and the alien sight of a mushroom cloud over an explosion, place exotica in their contemporary worlds while also responding to earlier literary archetypes. Such retrospective gestures are integral to many of the discourses in which writing about exotica in early modern China were embedded. Our studies reveal a set of strategies that domesticated, classified, and politicized common knowledge of foreign objects and collective memories of strange spectacles. We combine literary history with discussions of ethnicity, urban space, visual and material culture to show how, in a broader sense, texts intersected with social realities, and more specifically, how writing the exotic framed meditations on the dynamics of familiar and strange, self and other, past and present.

session-title: Living with the Yangzi: Technology, State Power, and Environmental Change in the
text: The Central Yangzi River basin was once among the largest wetlands in Asia, but is now a fertile agricultural region and the economic core of central China. In order to live in this dynamic hydraulic system, humans have transformed it, a process that began as early as Hunans 7000-year-old rice paddies and culminated with Hubeis Three Gorges Dam. While a few Western-language studies discuss the regions environmental history from c. 1500 to 1949, this panel seeks to expand the temporal frame by surveying earlier and later developments. Our goal is to explore how people have dealt with the dominance of water in this region over an extended period of time and, in turn, how that long history affected state-led waterworks in the twentieth century. Central to our analyses are interactions between the regions hydrology and various state actors, technologies, and laboring bodies. The first paper considers the regions transformation over the millennia since farming began, focusing on the interplay of demographics and state-led water control projects. The second focuses on how people moved within this water-world, adapting to seasonal and longer term environmental changes. The third focuses on the 1950s, when the new communist government mobilized mass labor and new technologies to turn much of Dongting Lake into productive rice fields. The final paper looks at the conception and construction of the Three Gorges Dam, which was arguably built for ideological as much as hydrological reasons, and has profoundly disrupted the seasonal cycle of the lowlands.

session-title: Communist Processes and Mao-Era Policies in the Ethnic Borderlands of Western
text: Over the past few decades, an increasing amount of scholarship has been published on Mao-era political and social campaigns, including land reform, the Great Leap Forward, collectivization, and the Cultural Revolution. However, the majority of this scholarship has focused on areas of the country that are predominately inhabited by ethnic Han Chinese residents. In Chinas ethnic borderland regions, political campaigns often followed different timelines and led to different social and political outcomes than in Han majority areas. What were some of the biggest hurdles that the Communist Party faced in spreading socialist policies into rural ethnic minority areas? How informed were Han Communist Party leaders about local social, religious, and political conditions in diverse regions of the country and to what extent did the Party adjust its policies to account for ethnic and religious differences in these regions? What were the backgrounds and motivations of the Kazakh, Hui, and Tibetan cadres who joined the Chinese Communist Party and carried out policies in their local communities? In addressing these questions, this interdisciplinary panel draws on data collected through ethnographic research, oral history interviews, and close readings of Chinese government documents in Yunnan Province, the Tibetan Autonomous Region, and the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region. Panelists analyze the ways in which particular Tibetan, Hui, and Kazakh communities participated in land reform, collectivization, and the Cultural Revolution, and they demonstrate how villagers memories of Mao-era policies are often at variance with the written accounts stored in archives or recorded in Chinese government publications.

session-title: Jiang Qing (1914-1991) from Multiple Perspectives
text: In this panel, international scholars specializing in art, history, film, and theater juxtapose their distinct lenses to bring forth interdisciplinary understandings of Jiang Qing (1914-1991) that extend beyond historical and political interpretations of Jiang Qing as the wife of Mao Zedong and ringleader of the Gang of Four. This panel will offer interpretations of Jiang Qing as a left-wing performer of drama and film in 1930s Shanghai, as the subject of a wealthy transnational biographical industry, and as the target of caricatures loaded with specific cultural references. These analyses will illuminate new understandings of Jiang Qing that contribute to modern and contemporary Chinese representations of gender, the genre of biography in China and the West, and the use of visual language in socio-political changes in early post-Cultural Revolution China. They will also suggest through conflict and comparison alternative modes of thinking within and across the above disciplines.

session-title: Establishing and Reading a Han Text: Recent Studies of Sima Qians Shiji
text: This panel includes four papers that explore both the original text of and recent studies on Sima Qians Shiji. Hans van Esss Thoughts on Recent Studies on the Shiji and Han shu provides a framework for the panel by examining the studies in China of these two closely related Han-dynasty texts from the 1960s through the present day, drawing important conclusions concerning the gradual diminishing interest in both texts in the Chinese academy. Weiguo Caos Mythical Accounts in the Grand Scribes Records takes a comparative approach to Sima Qians predilection for the marvelous, utilizing traditional commentaries and parallel passages in other early texts as a key to Sima Qians motives for including such accounts. Marc NÃ_rnbergers Notions of Text as Presented by the Shiji is once again concerned with the text, but NÃ_rnbergers interests are in how traditional commentaries shaped the notion of the work as a text as well as how it should be read. William H. Nienhauser, Jr.s Concerning the Received Text of the Shiji focuses on the text of the new (2014) Zhonghua version of chapter 123, The Memoir on Ferghana, noting the problems that remain in this edition and what they mean for readers of the Shiji in the future. The panel thus affords scholars interested in the Shiji with an introduction to scholarship both traditional and modern as well as guidelines for reading, studying and translating the text in the future.

session-title: (In)visible Body in Motion: Visual Practices and Social Movements in Modern China
text: The panel examines the dialectics of (in)visibility in relation to the multilayered frictions between the state and the individual body. Visualization, the magic of making perceptible and thus knowable, has long been integral to the states art of governance. The process of re-ordering social relations, nonetheless, is full of crevices and apertures that produce possibilities of creative re-appropriation, re-circulation, and seeing otherwise. Visual practices in the volatile history of modern China thus serve as a privileged arena for social and political contestation, providing mechanisms for both mobilization of and resistance by grassroots actors. The body exposed to the perils of visualization also complicates the power dynamics by making visible what would be infinitesimal, ephemeral, repressed, or silenced. The panel starts with Shaoqian Zhangs paper on the representation of the negative aspects of the New Woman around the time of the New Life Movement. Lu Liu argues that visual abjection in the Four Pests Campaign participates in the making of human subjects through creating a hygienic/political category of the pest. Yang Wang examines visualizations of peasants through a hybridized genre of figure painting that ameliorated anxieties about the growing urban-rural divide. Nick Smith investigates the use of graffiti as resistance to urban redevelopment and demolition, exploring how the materiality of this visual practice appropriates the idiom of official discourse and evades restrictions on public speech. The four papers, following the production, circulation, reception, and re-production of visual practices, altogether explore the politics of visual economy and the visuality of political movements.

session-title: Through Fractured Lenses: Revisiting Revolutionary Chinese Cinema and Its
text: The cinematic legacies of the Maoist era are hotly debated today. How to reevaluate this multitudinous heritage as well as its afterlives is the subject of this panel. While a veneer of uniformity often covers its remembrance, the papers in this panel take a variety of comparative approaches, both geographical and historical, to resuscitate the heterogeneous products, experiences, and effects of Chinese revolutionary cinema, both then and in the post-revolutionary present. Investigating the Peoples Republic of Chinas (PRC) cinematic transactions with East and West Germany in the 1950s, Thomas Chen demonstrates the unorthodox ways in which films were received that cut across the demarcation of the socialist and capitalist worlds. In her paper Qian He likewise challenges border-drawing and the construction and deconstruction of dichotomous identities in looking at contemporaneous portrayals of the "struggle session" in films from the PRC and the Republic of China (ROC). In reading the experience of Maoist moviegoing as torture, Chenshu Zhou proposes an alternative conception of cinemas link with the body. Finally, Zhuoyi Wang analyzes how a remake of a red classic reveals its repressed hybridity and the uses to which it is currently put in the context of global capitalism. These four papers show how cinema of the revolutionary period continues to prompt the redrawing of boundaries and the reanimation of bodies.

session-title: Engaging a Closing China
text: International engagement with China is increasingly difficult. Within China, a deepening domestic political chill is steadily limiting the space for international exchanges in a range of fields, including business, government, academia, civil society, media, and culture. Foreign actors are finding it more challenging to maintain existing programs and activities in China, and to build new contacts among Chinese counterparts.  Internationally, political shifts in the West have contributed to rising tensions between China and the outside world. In America, the Trump administration has publicly questioned key tenets of the US-China relationship. In Australia, the influence of mainland China within Australian university campuses and community groups has emerged as a hot-button domestic political issue. This panel will explore both the reasons for the conservative turn in Chinas domestic politics, and the options facing international actors that have been engaged with China, some since the beginning of the reform era.  How should key international groups operating in China - including major private foundations, top Western universities, and key global cultural institutions - respond to the tightening operating space? How might these trends affect long-standing educational relationships between China and the West, from foreign Ph.D students seeking to do academic research in Chinese archives to the hundreds of thousands of Chinese students currently enrolled in schools overseas? And what is the appropriate role of Western governments in responding to these trends? This roundtable panel will embrace an innovative format: presentations will be kept very short (5-8 minutes), to encourage discussion among the panelists, and also with the audience. In addition, each panelist will be encouraged to discuss the above questions through the prism of his or her own on-the-ground experience: Elizabeth Knup and Tom Kellogg will talk about the ways in which foreign foundations have responded to the challenging environment; Orville Schell will discuss how a major US-based NGO has responded; and Carl Minzner and John Fitzgerald will discuss the ways in which international academic collaboration has been impacted by recent trends. In addition to serving as chair, Kaiser Kuo will discuss the impact on the business sector.

session-title: (Re)claiming the Womb: Abortion, Reproductive Hygiene, and the Fickle State in
text: This panel examines the evolution of the field of reproductive medicine and the concentration and dispersal of state power throughout twentieth-century China. By investigating four successive periods spanning the Republican (1911-1949) and Mao (1949-1976) eras, we highlight how approaches to reproductive medicine changed along with shifting political anxieties and societal concerns. As state power and commitment waxed and waned, diverse views about health and gender roles, local contingencies, and inconsistent policies frequently undermined efforts to standardize reproductive practices. From the perspective of high level state actors and reformist elites, reproductive medicine offered possibilities for disseminating proper gender roles, delineating ethnic hierarchies, and curtailing deviant behaviors. At the same time, patients and individuals practicing medicine at the grassroots private practitioners, Barefoot Doctors, and Ethnic Hygiene Teams played a critical role in contesting, implementing, and redirecting the states medical agenda. Ling Ma and Sarah Mellors trace the shift from Republican era natalism to aggressive population planning during the 1970s, illuminating how state efforts to promote certain reproductive practices and limit others had unforeseen and deeply gendered consequences. Shenglan Li and Xiaoshun Zeng highlight how efforts to reform minority communities reproductive practices during the Republican era paved the way for so-called ethnic hygiene programs in the early Peoples Republic. By focusing on reproductive medicine, these four papers demonstrate the centrality of the womb to Nationalist and Communist statecraft and the ways in which medical practitioners and patients shaped these projects.

session-title: Contextualizing (un)queer Kinship: Family Change, Transnational Mobilities, and
text: Family practices by people practicing homoeroticism in China have to date been researched primarily under the rubric of sexuality studies, which places an overemphasis on the role of sexual identities and leaves the heteronormative assumption of family and family studies intact (Brainer, 2017). This interdisciplinary panel challenges this long-existing intellectual division of labor by probing the structural, relational, sociospatial, and gendered contingencies of both queerness and kinship. Panelists from the fields of Sociology, Gender Studies, and Media Studies shed light on various family practices associated homoeroticism in Chinese societies, including long-term same-sex couplehood and parenthood, family acceptance of homosexual children, transnational migrations impact on stretched kinship and gay mens decision to enter heterosexual marriage. Drawing from empirical and representational materials and blending ethnographic and textual approaches, they uncover the process whereby non-normative sexualities, conjugality, and parenthood may be embedded within the Chinese/Confucian family/kinship/marriage system. Specifically, this panel asks: What is queer (and unqueer) about these conjugal, intergenerational, and marital practices? What forms of values/norms are upheld and constructed by different agents in family, challenging certain dimensions of heteronormativity while leaving other facets intact? How are Chinese conceptions of the family in turn impacted by homoerotic desires, sexual liaisons, and even formal partnership and parenthood? By laying bare the imbrication of both the queer/disruptive/anti-normative and the unqueer/conformist/normative components in Chinese family dynamics and mapping territories of ambiguity in the landscape of both kinship and queerness, this panel explores recent theoretical calls for queering family of origin and queer theory without antinormativity.

session-title: Imagining Foreignness: Race, Nation, and the Body in Early Modern Chinese
text: This panel engages interdisciplinary dialogues on race, the body, and transnational imaginations of foreignness in early modern Chinese literary and historical narratives, focusing on these questions: How do Chinese representations of foreigners and foreignness expand canonical boundaries of discourses about race and ethnicity? How do representations of racialized and/or sexualized bodies in early modern narratives generate new understandings of self and other, and at the same time echo the emerging discourse of nation? What models of body politics do narratives of and about foreign bodies in early modern Chinese literary and historical writings produce? What social and political analogy could such models of body politics produce? How does sexualization of racial ambivalence and ethnic identities problematize gaze, spectatorship, voyeurism, and imaginations of the Other? Seeking to address these questions, this panel provides four papers on the following topics: 1) representations of Burmas last king Thibaw, whose fate for late Qing and early Republican Chinese intellectuals became the very embodiment of a failed nation; 2) depictions of foreign princesses in nineteenth-century Chinese chantefable novels and shifting discourses of gender and nationhood; 3) discussions of gender order and female sexuality at the center of late Qing lawmakers debates over Chinese national essence in relation to Western civilizations; 4) the impact of emerging Chinese nationalism on representations of the Tibetan body. Collectively, the panelists explore how representations of foreign bodies in early modern Chinese narratives project new modes of empathy and cross-cultural identification, and yield nascent expressions of desire, motives and geopolitical aspirations.

session-title: Local Gazetteers as a Database: New Digital Research Methods
text: Gazetteers are an important genre of text, lying somewhere between local histories and geographies. But while gazetteers are full of text they are not a purely textual genre. They are full tables and lists composed of bits of numerical and textual data, often with cross-references. This data was not intended to be read cover-to-cover, rather it served as reference material and collective summary. With the advent of digital technologies, textual materials have become far more accessible than ever before. The large scale of digital materials fundamentally changes the types of questions we can ask. Where these sources contain structured data, they should not be treated strictly as text. LoGaRT is a suite of tools built specifically for tagging and extracting data from gazetteers. It allows gazetteers to be used not just individually to look up information, but collectively as a database. Our four panelists will give presentations considering the format and structure of gazetteers as sources and the methodological implications of using them as a database. Shih-Pei Chen will begin by demonstrating the capabilities of the LoGaRT tools that the other presenters used in their research. Qun Che used LoGaRT to track environmental change connected to  water conservancy projects, Joseph Dennis used it to construct a database of school library book collections, and Ian Miller to analyze the structure and compilation of numerical tax data. To leave maximum time for audience participation we will convene this panel without a discussant and keep presentations to no more than 10 minutes.

session-title: New Perspectives on Chinese Political Economy: Firms as Agents of Change
text: What is the political role of capitalists and business in China? While a great deal of scholarship has examined how party-state institutions and intergovernmental arrangements have contributed to or hindered Chinas growth, far fewer scholars have examined firms as agents of economic change and authors of Chinas unique system. This panel brings together papers by scholars of diverse geography, rank, and background on the theme of firms as actors in reform-era China. The papers examine interactions between firms and the Chinese state, taking different approaches to how business behavior affect state power and induce institutional change. Ling Chens paper (with Florian Hollenbach) uses a large dataset of firms effective tax rates between 1996-2008 to argue that firms with mobile assets have greater bargaining power vis-Ã -vis local governments and are better able to extract tax incentives. Lizhi Liu (with Barry Weingast) argues that the CCP has off-loaded legal development tasks to private firms and, using the case of the online retailer Taobao, shows how firms create rule of law in a weak legal environment. Xiaojun Li and Meg Rithmire both look at the role of firms in shaping Chinas internationalization. Li (with Ka Zheng) uses a unique survey of Chinese manufacturing firms to understand their motivations for joining (or not joining) projects as a part of Chinas One Belt One Road initiative. Rithmire looks at outward investments of firms of all types of ownership to argue that going global has attenuated the power of the CCP by facilitating corrupt asset expatriation.

session-title: State Control in Unexpected Places and Unexpected Ways: Lessons from China
text: The Chinese state is a vast bureaucracy that oversees many aspects of society, but state control is about more than just streamlining infrastructure projects, promoting economic development, or clamping down on dissent. This panel looks at how the Chinese state is exercising control in unexpected places and unexpected ways. Two of the papers explore state intervention in areas of society where the government has seemingly little interest. Fang investigates the ways in which Chinas propaganda apparatus is censoring and shaping pop culture content, while Hans paper looks at state influence over the production and consumption of internet novels. Both papers demonstrate how the state is moving deeper into cultural territory through censorship and the promotion of content that invokes national themes. The remaining papers investigate exercises of state control in China that run counter to our expectations. Scoggins details the efficacy of public relations campaigns implemented by the police bureaucracy to offset the agencys increasingly contentious relationship with the public, and Yao taps into new sources to show how state agents mitigated cultural heritage destruction during the Cultural Revolution. Taken together, these papers present a varied portrait of the Chinese state that reveal much about state priorities and behavior when it comes to controlling the cultural narrative and the image of the state.

session-title: Teaching Chinese Literature as World Literature: Lu Xun as an Exemplar
text: One of the foremost writers in early twentieth-century China, Lu Xun is widely known for his literary works that delineate and reformulate the national spirit of Chinese people. However, to what extent can we read his works as an example that illuminates the study of world literature, which emphasizes the long-standing phenomenon of transcultural and translational practices? A hundred years have passed since Lu Xun published his A Madmans Diary (1918), arguably the first modern Chinese fiction that inspired the entire May Fourth generation and beyond. What does it mean to study and teach Lu Xun in the English-speaking world during the twenty-first century in which we are faced with an ever increasing demand for a dialogue between disciplines and fields of studies? In particular, how can Lu Xuns works shed light on the relation between world and national literatures, the connection between personal memory and national narrative, and the conversations between Sinophone studies and Chinese literature? These are the questions that this roundtable aims to explore. Christopher Lupke addresses the question of why teaching Lu Xun is essential to world literary studies and explores the possibility of teaching Lu Xun from an interdisciplinary perspective. Jon von Kowallis discusses the translations of Lu Xuns classical-style poetry in both Chinese and English-speaking contexts. Ping Zhu analyzes issues related to gender and colonial modernity in Lu Xuns works and reveals their pedagogical implications. Nick Admussen examines ways in which Lu Xuns Wild Grass can be taught by emphasizing the works aesthetic, psychological, and political implications. Carlos Yu-Kai Lin highlights the role of Lu Xun as a literary historian whose works exemplify how a modern, Western literary form is built into and fascinated by local materials. Alexa Alice Joubin will chair the roundtable and make closing remarks on the inseparability of the studies of world and national literatures.

session-title: Minority Elites and the Early Maoist State: Cooperation, Accommodation and
text: While the 1949 establishment of the Peoples Republic of China (PRC) has long been seen as the central dividing line in twentieth-century Chinese history, recent research has demonstrated important continuities in many spheres of life between Republican and Maoist China. These continuities were often especially notable in minority areas, where the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) typically had little presence before 1949, and was thus reliant on pre-revolutionary local elites for much of the 1950s. This panel will explore these crucial cooperative relationships referred to as the United Front between the CCP and indigenous elites in Chinese minority regions and borderlands. Scholars have rarely considered the United Front as more than cynical expediency. Yet, as Lyman Van Slyke noted, by 1949 the United Front had developed from tactic to strategy to ideology. The United Front had become fundamental to the framework through which the CCP and minority communities understood and interacted with each other, as the party sought to inculcate Maoist ideology and local elites worked to retain their own influence. Ranging from Chinas southwestern borderlands to the Tibetan Plateau to the Muslim regions of the far northwest, members of this panel will outline the formation, functioning and significance of United Front alliances between the CCP and pre-revolutionary minority elites, and will examine how these partnerships ultimately disintegrated under the strain of Maoist radicalization. The panel will provide a fresh perspective on the establishment of Party rule in borderland regions and the integration of minority communities into the emerging structures of the PRC.

session-title: Winning Hearts, Minds, and Bodies in Communist China
text: Scholars have examined the history of medicine and the body in Communist China by unpacking the relationship between Traditional Chinese Medicine and biomedicine as well as between diseases and society. This panel seeks to re-center the critical role that communist ideology played in persuading the Chinese people that a revolutionary China required new modes of healing, consumption, mobilization, and maintenance of the body. Although efforts at nurturing new behaviors were often disrupted by unexpected agents such as fortune tellers, Overseas Chinese, canteen operators, and medical personnel, their opposition was attenuated by the affective regime of Communism, which constrained their resistance toward new regimes of biopower. Through four case studies, this panel will show how communism necessitated a fundamental reorientation of the individual body to its surroundings. Mary Augusta Brazelton will examine how immunization became a significant site of conflict between the state and people over the implementation of government policies in the early PRC. Wayne Soon will investigate how the Overseas Chinese introduced a global and cosmopolitan form of biomedicine in wartime Yanan, challenging the nativist and nationalist rhetoric that colored existing understandings of medicine and society in the region. Emily Baum will show how the Communists sought to curb fortune-telling practices by replacing individual forms of spirituality with a Party-sanctioned materialism. Seung-joon Lee will present on the history of food politics in the early PRC, revealing how the use of canteens in the Kuomintang period continued to haunt similar efforts at mobilizing nutritional standards by the Communists.

session-title: Chinese Climate Change and Environment: Government and Citizen Reactions and
text: This panel looks at governmental and public reactions to climate change and pollution in China: To what extent do citizens wish their local government prioritizes environmental protection, and what factors influence such demand? Where does the public engagement for environmental protection come from? Compared to other priorities such as public goods provision, how strong is the public desire for environmental protection? What are provincial level governments doing to curb GHG emissions and tackle pollution? Which effects has the revised Environmental Protection Law (2015) which strengthens both administrative measures as well as citizen participation, had in provincial jurisdictions? While it is often reported that Chinese local governments environmental protection enforcement is poor, the situation of addressing climate change and curbing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is not equally dismal. What can explain GHG mitigation without the implementation gap? Current environmental reactions and interactions are shaping Chinese society and politics in ways we do not yet fully understand. In order to illuminate the mechanisms and dynamics that occur within this domain, this panel invites papers which systematically and empirically address aspects of environmental governance from the perspectives of those who govern, and of the affected population.

session-title: Hong Kong as a Postcolony: Twenty Years of Chinese Rule
text: Postcolonial Hong Kong is a world historic experiment on the co-existence between a liberal capitalist society and its authoritarian communist sovereign. The past two decades of Hong Kong- Mainland integration and contention have inspired popular fears of recolonization or internal colonization, by China, but also new passion and imagination among the younger generation and civil society activists about Hong Kongs political future. The 2014 Umbrella Movement, in which 1.2 million citizens participated in the 79-day occupy movement in downtown Hong Kong, was just the tip of an iceberg. This watershed event was both the culmination and the source of deep- seated institutional, political and economic conflicts and struggles involving different segments of Hong Kong society, the Hong Kong Government, and Beijings proxies in the territory. Taking stock of twenty years of momentous change, this panel analyzes Hong Kongs postcolonial transformation under Chinese rule in four key arenas: political economy, rule of law, migration, and cultural production. Together, the papers address these questions --  Do Chinas economic interests in Hong Kong conflict with its political imperatives of control? Why has rule of law become an intensely contested terrain in Hong Kong-Mainland relation, and with what consequences for Hong Kongs political economic future? How are Mainland Chinese migrants to Hong Kong racialized and ethnicized, spurring an anti-immigrant nativist movement? How has the Hong Kong film industry navigated its integration with the Chinese market, with what consequences for Hong Kongs cultural production and identity?

session-title: Translating Classical Texts of Political Economy and International Law into Chinese
text: This panel adopts a dual, text-centred and biographical approach to the intellectual history of the introduction of concepts of Western political economy and international law into China. Importantly, it gives agency to translators. All of the translators considered were important scholars in their own right. All of them made important choices in their translation, and, through their translations, shaped the modern Chinese vocabulary. The panel engages with a series of questions most fundamentally, what is a translation? Is it a recreation of a text? How much linguistic innovation is a standard part of translation? Or, in other words, are these translations unusual? The panel also considers the biographical influences on translations, by asking how life stories affect translation projects. How does one translate texts about capitalist/early capitalist societies into a language which is based in a country which is not a capitalist society? What is the role of the translator? What are the particular challenges of translating a text into Chinese? Also, does the translation of a text change over time, and how does the environment for translating such texts change over time? What do the translations show about the translators understandings of political economy and, later, economics? Suns paper advances the study of translations of Wheatons Elements of International Law beyond the standard accounts of WAP Martins translation; Karls paper explores the feminist roots of the first Chinese translation of Das Kapital, and Boeckings paper shows how, even in 2001, Smith gave authority to debates aboute the role of prices.

session-title: The Second Buddha: New Perspectives on Padmasambhava
text: This panel concerns literary and artistic traditions surrounding the legendary eighth-century tantric master, Padmasambhava. This culture heros mythology began in Tibet and the eastern Himalayas, where he is conceived of as a second Buddha, in some ways more powerful or important than the historical Buddha. His importance to the cultural life of Asia is vast - whether measured by the geographic distance between sacred sites devoted to him in Tibet, Mongolia, China, Nepal, Bhutan, and India or by the hundreds of volumes of literature recounting his life and teachings.  His portrayals in art date from at least the thirteenth century, shortly followed by his earliest literary description as the second Buddha.  At present, he is one of the most globally recognizable figures in Tibetan iconography. The participants in this panel focus on a diverse set of texts, images, narratives, histories and built structures related to Padmasambhava. Elena Pakhoutova investigates the purposes and functions of visual narratives about Padmasambhava in the Himalayas, which incorporate earlier elements of popular Buddhist narrative. Lewis Doney addresses the impact of the earliest Padmasambhava biography on the stratification of Inner Asian Buddhist societies. Daniel A. Hirshberg explains the manifestations of Padmasambhava in liturgy, hagiography and iconography within the context of Tibetan Buddhist tantric traditions. Benjamin Bogin explores the construction of temples representing Padmasambhavas palace in Tibet, Nepal, and the United States. Together, these papers offer insight into the cultural dynamics surrounding one of the most important and understudied figures in the history of Buddhist Asia.

session-title: China Vice: Defining and Dealing with the Modern Criminal Element
text: This panel explores the concept and experience of criminality in modern China. It looks at how authorities have defined certain activities as criminal and prosecuted them, as well as how such activities have been experienced by community members and other local actors. Kidnappers, crooks, pornographers, and swindlers: papers examine four archetypical criminal types and why they mattered from the perspectives of state and society between the late Qing and the early Mao era. Quinn Javers shows why communities and officials resorted to or supported kidnapping in late Qing Sichuan; while proscribed by statute, this form of illegal justice had both material and didactic effects. Weiting Guo focuses on how villagers in Zhejiang participated in gambling, opium consumption, and violence, as well as in campaigns against such villainy. Yvon Wang examines to what extent so-called yellow, or pornographic, print material survived Mao era campaigns against it, highlighting significant continuities in how licentiousness was regulated across the 1949 divide. Christopher Rea shows how and why the Maoist party-state became obsessed with swindlers, imposters, and spies infiltrating the revolutionary ranks in the 1950s, going so far as to mobilize writers to churn out stories about con men. Each study draws on archival sources to reveal tensions between individual expediency (e.g., detaining a debtor), market demand (e.g., for opium or gambling), social stability (e.g., campaigns against frauds), and ideological imperatives (e.g., to ban licentious materials). Taken together, they reveal the contested and ever-shifting bounds of vice and criminality in modern China.

session-title: Commoner Mobility in the Early Chinese Empires
text: This panel investigates, for Chinas late pre-imperial and early imperial period, the social, cultural, and geographical dimensions of commoner mobility.  Whereas the role of travel by high officials and generals in the constitution of the early empires is generally understood, other groups too should be considered.  Our panel has two interrelated scholarly aims.  First, it will shine the spotlight on the mobility of groups of commoners scribes, members of the lower orders, soldiers, conscripts, or merchants to try to determine to what extent their mobility was free or was restricted by government mandates and regulations, and to gage the impact of private and professional mobility on the lives of the commoners who were on the move.  Second, as a focused examination of a concrete, but complex, historical topic, the panel will make a case for the importance of integrating diverse source bases.  Excavated texts (including legal sources) are of crucial importance to understand a topic such as commoner mobility. However, they need to be weighted critically, and brought into dialogue with one another, with transmitted texts, and with the human landscape of early China.   This is a difficult and complex task, that requires reflection and cooperation among scholars. Each presentation will be short, and focused both on an aspect of commoner travel and a particular source base, so as to allow the kind of dialogue, among panelists and with the audience, we think is necessary to move the field of early Chinese history forward.

session-title: Red Love and Love Red: Gendered, Sexualized and Affective Linkages of Socialist
text: Accounts of Chinas social transformation often presume a rupture between socialism and postsocialism. This narrative simplifies complex power struggles between the state and the mass, erases revolutionary agency of socialism, and serves to justify the dominance of neoliberal ideology. To challenge this narrative, the panel explores dynamic relations between socialist history and postsocialist present through the lens of gender, sexuality and affect. Drawing from recent debate on the usage of FunÃ_, Xin Huang analyzes how historical legacy of Mao-era womens liberation, has contradictorily shaped current feminist movements in China. Tracing various attitudes towards womens menstruation leave in the 1950-60s and the present, Yiyu Tian views menstruation as an affective site where women utilize their body as creative strategies to negotiate with state power. Shana Ye explores the queer potential of reconstructing narrative of sexual violence into radical politics of resistance by providing a close reading of a memoir by a gay man who was prosecuted in the Cultural Revolution. Charlie Zhang brings the issue of affect and queerness to the transpacific level. Linking the ascendancy of Peter Le with queer entrepreneurial strategies used by Chinese (gay) men, he provides a new understanding of value creation and extraction in the age of transnational neoliberalism dependent on circulation driven by expectations, rather than production and consumption. Together, the papers search for a robust critical language to contest the Cold-War informed neoliberal construction of socialist China, and explore new possibilities of gendered agency from the past to shed light on todays struggle.

session-title: Digital Methods for Traditional Chinese Literary Studies
text: Recent advances in the field of digital humanities applied to Chinese literary studies have led to the creation of new methodologies designed to exploit the full potential of digital source materials and computational technologies. The papers to be presented in this panel have been specifically selected to highlight four different digital sinological methodologies, each centered upon a new digital corpus developed by the presenter. Drawn from articles to be included in a forthcoming special edition of the Journal of Chinese Literature and Culture, this panel will demonstrate the benefits of a variety of computational methods in the analysis of premodern Chinese literary practices. Jeffrey Tharsens paper is centered upon comparative linguistic and phonorhetorical analyses and visualizations of parallel passages in the early Chinese works Zuozhuan and Guoyu. Evan Nicoll-Johnsons paper demonstrates how network analyses can provide a more in-depth picture of reading practices and the circulation of books and documents during the Northern and Southern Dynasties. Mariana Zorkinas paper is focused on a corpus-linguistics analysis of specific clichs and their use throughout Tang literature. Wang Zhaopeng will present his five-year statistical study of the geographical distribution and displacement of Tang-Song poets, based on text mining of commentaries and secondary sources. We are particularly grateful to Cai Zong-Qi, one of the worlds foremost experts in premodern Chinese literary analysis, and Liu Chao-Lin, one of sinologys most renowned digital humanists, for agreeing to serve as discussants for this panel.

session-title: Of Reds and Experts: Socialist Science, Technology, and Medicine in Maoist China
text: Recent scholarship in the history of Chinese science, technology, and medicine has rewritten the failure narrative that had previously characterized accounts of scientific endeavors in Maoist China. Rather than dismissing the period as being entirely inhospitable to the scientific enterprise, this work has demonstrated ways in which individuals from citizen masses to professional experts participated in the making of science under socialism. From grassroots medicine and fish farming to agricultural mechanization and coal mining, our panel showcases attempts by different circles of experts papered and otherwise to adopt and adapt science to the ideological, material, and environmental constraints of the socialist state. Gross explores how rural medicine emerged as distinct from professional and state-sponsored medicine, demonstrating that the spectrum of political positions within the Party was also reflected in on-the-ground medical practices. Jiang traces how aquaculture experts justified their research in genetic and embryological science otherwise classified as bourgeois by framing this work in Marxist terms, and laid the foundation for future successes in fish farming. Rogaski examines, through the case of Beidahuang, how socialist dreams of landscape transformation through technological inputs were thwarted by the treachery of terrain. And Seow looks at how the impulse to compete with capitalist countries in industrial output kept thermal efficiency low even as more and more coal was being extracted and consumed by the socialist machine. Together, these papers highlight the tensions between ideology and expertise, state and society, and visions and reality that underpinned the making of socialist science in the Peoples Republic.

session-title: Connoisseur-Researchers, Musical Notations and the Shengping Shu Archive:
text: The birth of modern studies of xiqu (Chinese song-drama) as a discipline occurred in a pivotal moment in early twentieth-century China. The global competitions over collecting and interpreting theatre-related materials prompted Chinese researchers to reexamine the place of xiqu in the Chinese cultural tradition and among world civilizations. This panel examines how the emerging modern studies of xiqu were shaped by new interpretive methodologies, an expanding conception of study materials and the availability of previously unseen performance materials.  Panelists will investigate three distinct cases in which early Republican-era scholars and artists evaluated and used study materials as they established and expanded the studies of xiqu in new directions. Hsiao-Chun Wu examines the studies of Qi Rushan and other scholars to show how Chinese intellectuals emphasis on collecting as scientific method of humanistic research motivated drama scholars to explore a wider basis of research materials for knowledge production. Dongshin Chang explores how a shared common vision to promote kunqu domestically and globally motivated early Republican scholars and artists to revamp the system of musical notation. Liana Chen establishes the Shengping shu archive as the key element to early Republican scholars effort in documenting the artistic legacy of the Chinese imperial theatre. Professor Shana Brown of University of Hawaii at Manoa, an expert on modern Chinese intellectual history, will serve as the panel discussant. We suggest that specific methods of collecting and studying xiqu led to the creation of Chinese drama studies as a field of knowledge in the early Republican era.

session-title: After Conquest Dynasties
text: Scholars usually consider the differences between conquest dynasties and native dynasties in Chinese history as diminishing through the process of Sinicization, or simply had been obliterated by the subsequent native dynasties. Following this perspective through the entire course of Chinese history, the reign of conquest dynasties could be considered as a detour, especially in terms of political history. This panel wants to debate this viewpoint by investigating the legacy of conquest dynasties through the lens of those native dynasties behind them. Sanping Chen first discusses the Xianbei legacy of assistant conquerors in the Tang Dynasty by comparing different conquest dynasties with an emphasis on the Xianbei regimes. With a focus on the context of rituals, Zhan Beibei then looks into an early Ming imperial marriage ritual case to analyze the underlying Mongol legacy in the Ming court. Francesca Fiaschetti investigates the dynastic succession during Yuan-Ming to discuss the practical aspects (such as military, economical) of Mongol legacy in the East Asia during Ming era. Fangyi Cheng closes the panel with a discussion on the evolution of Sinicization theory applied in different contexts by both Chinese and Western scholars in late 19th and 20th Centuries. By looking at dynastic alternations in terms of legacy rather than "transition", the panel demonstrates the significance of the conquest dynasties in Chinese history is often downplayed, and highlights elements of mutual influence between strategies of government in China and Inner Asia. It thus reviews the position of China in the broader context of Eurasian history.

session-title: Digital China: Decenter and Deconstruction
text: This panel examines the digitization in and of Chinese culture in the new millennium. It concerns but is not limited to the following issues: how do digital techniques transform the social reality and create new ways of representation? Particularly, how are various sectors of culture reshaped by the arrival and dissemination of digital technology? What role does digitization play in negotiating the form, content, politics, and ethics in different ramifications of culture? Song Shis paper investigates how digital media and communication technologies are used to empower Chinese NGOs. Andy Rodekohr considers how digital filmmaking and CGI-enhanced cinematic spectacles have transformed the imagination of the the masses in contemporary China. Enhua Zhang tackles the issues of digitization and dramatization, memory and anesthesia, private and public revolving around three recent films digital recreation of Tiananmen Square. Based on the India-born Indranis The Legend of Lady White Snake, Liang Luo presents the digitization of Chinese culture in the transnational context and questions the relationship between digital-ness and plasticity, subject-making and metamorphosis. As a whole, this panel demonstrates the multifaceted use of digital technology in the spectacular construction of film, memory, performances, and social change. The four papers also each engage with the concept of marginalization: queer mentality and intermedial experimentation in Luos paper, marginalized grassroots NGOs in Songs paper, the anachronistic notion of the masses in Andys paper, and, in Zhangs case, the the resonance of individual memory in the face of state-sanctioned mythmaking.

session-title: Mobility and Materiality in Early Modern China
text: This panel examines the ways in which mobility has shaped the meanings assigned to objects and knowledge in early modern China. Mobility and materiality have been studied extensively on their own, but rarely together. Materials are connected to the meaning of place, but those meanings are destabilized by trade and travel; goods contain value and knowledge, but these are problematized by strategies for transport and government censorship. This panel shows how different kinds of mobility transformed materiality and meaning. Anne Gerritsen explores how mobility and transience shaped the material record of the ceramics trade town of Wuchengzhen. Huiying Chen discusses the commodification of local products in eighteenth-century China, asking how the movement of travelers followed and redefined the meaning for a local delicacy the Jinhua Ham. Following jade from Xinjiang to Beijing, Yulian Wu examines how its materiality shaped transport tools and methods and Qing strategies of labor mobilization. Xue Zhang elucidates how duplicates of Jesuit maps were transmitted, uncovering a longstanding struggle between the diffusion and concealment of knowledge in nineteenth-century China. In different ways, these papers show that the movement of goods, regardless of whether this occurs through trade, travel, government transport, or knowledge transmission has had a transformative impact on the meaning of those goods. At the same time, the various modes of mobility are shaped by the materiality of the goods. We seek to show, therefore, that the interaction of materiality and mobility plays a key role in meaning-making and identity formulation in early modern China.

session-title: Postsocializing Queer Desires in China
text: Scholars of Chinese sexualities generally attribute the emergence of gay identities and communities in China to the end of socialism. However, the precise relation between Chinas sexual and economic liberalization remains unclear, especially since both postsocialism and gay identity remain controversial terms. While some critics challenge an unproblematic narrative of queer emancipation by exposing the neoliberal drive of pink economies as the true basis of contemporary LGBT visibility, others insist that the socialist legacy has been repurposed rather than abandoned by transnational capitalism. At the same time, newly available archives and oral histories of the Cultural Revolution produce a much more nuanced understanding of Chinas socialist regulations of bodies, pleasures, and sexual behavior than a simple repression/liberation model. This panel brings together divergent disciplinary methodologies (history, sociology, literature, and media studies) and clashing perspectives to build a dialogue around the relation between Chinas evolving political economy and sexual culture.

session-title: Late Imperial Chinese Commentaries Across the Jing (classics), Shi (history), Zi
text: Commentaries often expound on the meanings of words and passages, discuss styles and techniques, speculate authorial intentions, offer commentators evaluations, and thus influence readers interpretations of texts. Commentaries are thus crucial to our comprehension of the substance and significance of texts. In late imperial China, a huge number of commentaries appeared across four traditional bibliographical categories: jing (classics), shi (history), zi (master works), and ji (collected works). This panel elucidates late imperial Chinese commentaries in light of the following questions: what similarities and differences do commenting practices share in these four categories? How do commentaries shape the status of these works, and thus influence our understanding and reading of them? Pauli Tashima examines the jing section, explaining how pingdian contributed to canonical scholarship on the Zuo Tradition. Qin Fang explores the shi section, investigating the means by which poetic comments help construct and establish local history through a reading of the Haichang shenglan. Ji Hao explores the zi section, explicating the commentarial approaches that have led to various understandings of the nature of the novel Xi Youji. Lastly, Yue Zhang delves into the ji section, exploring Shen Deqians poetry anthology Gushi yuan by examining how Shens comments affect later readers understanding of literary style and status of Six Dynasties poets. The four papers place commentaries in larger historical and intellectual contexts, contributing to a better comprehension of the tradition of commentaries and their significance in influencing the meaning and status of the main texts.

session-title: Chinas Cosmopolitan Traditions
text: Modern Chinese literature has been intertwined with the world beyond Chinas borders in manifold ways. The cosmopolitan outlook of literary texts from the May Fourth period, the 1930s, and the 1980s, is generally acknowledged. Much less widely known are the efforts, of writers and readers alike, to engage the world during other periods, such as the War of Resistance Against Japan and the Cultural Revolution. Commitment to worldliness, however, was not restricted to isolated periods in Chinese literary history. Rather, its entanglement with global literary and cultural currents from the widest variety of sources is arguably one of the foundational features of modern Chinese literature. To probe this long tradition of interest in and commitment to literature and culture from abroad, this panel brings together papers that trace the cosmopolitan traditions of modern Chinese cultural production at some of its crucial junctions. Building on careful examinations of understudied texts and little known sources, the papers explore instances of worldliness such as Sino-Soviet theatrical exchanges in the 1950s, the Chinese career of an epic French novel, the consumption of foreign films during the Cultural Revolution, and the reception of Beat Generation literature in the 1960s and 1970s. Modern Chinas engagement with world literature and culture, the papers demonstrate, has given rise to a rich body of cosmopolitan traditions outward looking in conviction but by no means monolithic or uniform that have made Chinese literature and culture a truly global enterprise.

session-title: Comparative Yellow Perilisms: Imagination, Reaction, and Continuation
text: The rise of China in the 21st century has engendered a new wave of China Threat theory, which is often reminiscent of the Western discourse on the Yellow Peril popular in the early 20th century. In this context, studies on the ideology of Yellow Perilism have gained a renewed sense of political contingency. However, a careful examination of recent academic publications on the Yellow Peril reveals that the critique of Orientalism is still the dominant methodology used (Mel Chen 2012, Ruth Mayer 2013, John Kuo Wei Tchen and Dylan Yeats 2013, Christopher Frayling 2014, Madeline Hsu 2017). To counter this ongoing postcolonial obsession with the West, this panel proposes a comparative turn to study the Yellow Peril discourse as a set of interconnected and transnational phenomena across the long 20th century. Wendy Gan and Amy Matthewsons papers on the intertwinements between Chinoiserie and war in fin de siÃ¨cle British literary and visual culture bring in a broader view to go beyond the established tropes of Asian invasion and racial contamination, while Tobias Metzler examines the Japanese and Chinese reactions to Western Yellow Perilisms through analyses of historical government documents. The session will end with Xiaojian Zhaos paper on anti-Chinese sentiments in Italy, and together with the discussant Flairs Donglai Shis comments on the adaptions of the yellow peril discourse in China, contemporary continuations and mutations of the racist discourse will be put into comparative perspectives with its precedents in international cultural history.

session-title: Multifarious Modernities in the Cold War Sinophone Literature and Film from
text: During the Cold War, the 1949 divide brought about both divergent institutionalizations of national culture and corresponding counternarratives or subcultures in mainland China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan. While the diaspora of and communication among cultural agents within and outside these regions gave rise to heterogeneous national imaginaries, cultural activities, and socio-economic practices, the literary and film productions within these diverse loci envisioned different yet intertwined Chinese modernities. This panel aims to generate discussions on the way the Cold War Sinophone cultural productions throw up discrepant, antagonistic, sympathetic, or complicit ideological positions and cultural-economic relations across boundaries. Hsiu-Chuang Deppman delves into the gender politics in Eileen Changs Little Reunion and thinks about how its generic indeterminacy allows the writer to contest social norms at both local and global levels. Chialan Sharon Wang investigates the ambivalent Taiwanese national consciousness and palimpsest meaning-making processes in Zhong Lihes and Zhong Zhaozhengs novels and their later film adaptations. Jessica Tsui-yan Li looks into Zhong Xiaoyangs novel, Stopping by the Roadside and its film adaptation, A Pinwheel Without Wind, to unpack the notion of colonial modernity and examine the way ideological binaries are challenged in the Cold War Hong Kong cultural arena. Also foregrounding the obscured ideological oppositions in the urban films of Cold War Hong Kong, Lawrence Zi-QiaoYang scrutinizes the emergence of corporeal plasticity and immaterial labor in conjunction with the development of modern infrastructure, media, and technology in both pro-Taipei and pro-Beijing film productions.

session-title: Peering Through the Fog of Censorship: Studying Protest and Repression in China
text: What do we know about protests in China? Surprisingly much and, at the same time, very little. We know a great deal about micro-dynamics why protests emerge, how they are coordinated, what makes their success or failure likely, and how the state defuses or represses them. We know little, however, about the big picture. What is the distribution of protests over space, time and contentious domains? How do state responses vary over issues, tactics and social contexts? How have protester behavior and repression evolved? In contrast to previous times, when demonstrations were almost completely blacked out from the Chinese public sphere, the Internet, social media and even the Chinese press have over recent years brought to light an unprecedented amount of information about contentious events that researchers can exploit to answer these questions. To initiate a discussion on this new body of evidence, this panel brings together junior and senior scholars from three continents who are working with media-based protest event data sets Chen Chih-jou (Academia Sinica) examines what kinds of threats are most prone to trigger state coercion, and how protest policing has evolved over time. Manfred Elfstrom (Harvard) compares government responses to workers protests across ownership type. Li Yao (Harvard) and Manfred Elfstrom (Harvard) examine the link between coercive capacity and coercive application. Finally, Christoph Steinhardt (CUHK) and Christian GÃ¶bel (Vienna) shed light on the biases and validity of media-based protest event data. Kevin OBrien (Berkeley) will provide comments.

session-title: Techniques of Speaking: Sonic Intermediality in Republican China, Taiwan, and the
text: The sonic modernity of the twentieth century Sinosphere features an explosion of the techniques of speaking, listening, and silencing with which the operation of political propaganda, mass education, and cultural authority became effective and affective. Sitting in the intersection of sound studies, media archaeology, and history of technology, this panel interrogates the fundamental practice of speaking in the trans-medial environment of Republican China, colonial Taiwan, and the PRC. It seeks to understand how different techniques and technologies of speaking shaped the subject positions and collective identities of speakers, listeners, and readers. Starting with Republican China, Thorn Chens analysis of the multimedial lecture-screening identifies a shift of authority in the mass education from the speakers verbal diction to the global logistics of technical images. Laura Wen investigates the newspaper accounts of hassei eiga and their promotion of talkie screenings in colonial Taiwan, revealing the intricate relationship between modern media, technological cosmopolitanism, and colonial propaganda. Moving along, Ling Kang probes into the sonic technology in PRC films to de-fetishize the mass voice as a source of political and moral legitimacy in the socialist discourse. On the same vector, Yu Wangs paper traces the coming-into-being of the prototypical socialist voice manifested in the speaking manner of Chinese radio announcers in a Cold War context. Discussing lantern slides, newspaper, film, radio broadcasting, and human voice(s), this panel reconsiders the media and remediation of speaking on different structural and infrastructural levels such to historicize the heteroglossia of the modern Chinese soundscape and its cultural-political ramifications.

session-title: Changing Labour - Advocacy and Workers Agency in China
text: The panel draws on a rich vein of existing labour studies in China hitherto chiefly focused on manufacturing in Guangdong. We include the province but breach the borders of the great southern silo in three places. First, the panel spans four different industries across three sectors.  Second, the geographical range of the research reaches from Chengdu (shoes) to Beijing and Shanghai (construction) and sanitation in Guangzhou. Third, the panel moves away from well-researched state-society relations to the agency of workers themselves. The panel papers do not ignore the importance of recent significant legal and policy changes in state-(civil) society relations, but rather locate these developments in a dynamic and dialectical interaction with the the forces of labour to borrow from Beverly Silvers (2003) famous phrase. The big idea for this panel is that workers own actions lie at the heart of effective labour advocacy in whatever form. While far from original, the idea gains layers of complexity and tougher challenges in the context of well-known constraints on labour organising in China. The panellists hail from four universities in three countries with a gender balance favouring female participants. It is an interdisciplinary panel drawn from sociology, development studies and industrial relations and includes early career, established academics and a PhD candidate with an established publication record.  It is chaired by the Editor of China Quarterly. The discussant is a practitioner from an influential international labour rights advocacy organisation whose academic research focuses on labour in China.

session-title: Life Along the Silk Road
text: This panel aims to challenge the image of the so-called Silk Road, which usually highlights trade, especially long-distance trade, as its defining element. Such an oversimplification does not do justice to the complexities of local life. The Silk Road was not like a railway, where only the destinations and the cargo matter. Local affairs, we emphasize, were always peoples main concern, whereas the constant flow of goods, people, and ideas, often a byproduct of political turmoil, formed the backdrop of the societies along the Silk Road. Examining contracts, legal records, religious art, and military communications from Khotan, Kucha, Turfan, and Dunhuang, panelists will participate in a conversation led by the chair and discussant to discuss the roles of law, finance, military, and religion in and beyond the local communities at these four key sites on the Silk Road. We may hold a discussion and not give the usual 20-minute talks. Examining Tibetan military communications from Khotan, Chen Shen discusses the impact of the Tibetan occupation in Khotan. Based on a new edition of Khotanese documents, Zhan Zhang shows how Sogdians participated in the Khotanese taxation system as creditors. Analyzing contracts and legal records concerning slaves from Dunhuang and Turfan, Cuilan Liu discusses the legal implications of Buddhist monks and nuns involvement in the slave trade as buyers, sellers, and witnesses to transactions. Examining Buddhist paintings in Kucha, Monika Zin argues why visual images found on the Silk Road do not always reflect daily life.

session-title: Technologies of the Sublimed Self: Socio-technical Formations and Re-
text: Technologies have been conceptualized as a major dynamic in shaping and transforming the economic, political, and cultural status quo in East Asia. Meanwhile, many argue that the affordances of technologies have always been fulfilled within the existing social or institutional structures. The idea of socio-technical formations (e.g., Sassen 2012), however, emphasizes the ways in which interactions and collaborations between the social and technological factors engender new forms of identities, mechanism of governance, and social relations. Focusing on the booming business and financial fields in East Asia, this panel examines and contrasts how the ensemble of social and technological transformations has redefined the process of subjectivization in historically or culturally specific contexts. This innovative and interdisciplinary session will present various technological artifacts, interfaces, or interactive experiences obtained from our ethnographic works and engaged with economics or sociological concepts. Based on the history of semiconductor industry in Taiwan since the early 1990s, Lin examines the development of communication technologies and the formation of nationalistic identities among the high-tech workers in Hsinchu Science Park. Zhang depicts the new entrepreneurial work imaginaries among IT entrepreneurs in Beijings High-Tech Zone, situating them in Chinas post-socialist reform since the late 1970s. Wang studies the small individual investors in Shanghai using digital financial technologies to construct their new economic and social identities in and beyond the cyberspace. Finally, Kim conceptualizes financial subjectivities in South Korea after the Asian Financial Crisis in 1997, and studies how a specific trading technique influences individual perceptions of wealth, value and investment.

session-title: Risky Businesses: Banking, Insurance, and the Emergence of Modern Risk
text: From the 19th century, the Chinese market attracted growing numbers of foreign companies. Such firms not only brought new business forms into China, but also new notions of risk - no longer based on personal experience, but increasingly built on statistical evidence and quantified in numbers, tables and graphs. The introduction of this new understanding of risk created new risk-related knowledge about China, the creation of new business strategies for dealing with risk and the establishment of the first insurance companies in China. While measuring, assessing and dealing with different forms of risk became critical in the operations of both modern foreign and Chinese businesses since the 19th century, it has received little attention from historians. This panel addresses this research lacuna by exploring how modern concepts of risk were introduced and localized in China. By reconstructing the operations of foreign and Chinese businesses in two critical sectors banking and insurance this panels papers collectively show how firms in China found new ways to quantify and manage different kinds of risk and adapt European conceptualisations of risk to existing Chinese conditions. While the panel demonstrates how China became part of the evolving global risk network that sought to find uniform standards for assessing risk, it also stresses the role Chinese actors and local conditions played in shaping these standards. More broadly, this panel engages with key issues in the history of law, economy, business, and science, bringing a global perspective to a subject traditionally studied through the lens of Sino-foreign competition.

session-title: Digital Humanities and New Directions in Studying East Asian Art and Architecture
text: This panel presents four original digital humanities projects that enhance learning, researching, and exhibiting Asian art and architecture for the first time. In addition to seeking international and interdisciplinary collaborations with other scholars, each panelist employs digital technologies and methods, including automated computation, 3D scanning and modeling, and virtual reality, to reimagine the built environment. Li uses a formal tool in architecture and design called shape grammar to define portions of the Yingzao fashi, a Song dynasty (960-1279) court architectural manual central to the modern study of traditional Chinese architecture, as algorithms. Zhang will introduce a digital research database of historical buildings in China. His presentation considers new analytical technologies, challenges in terms of scholarly productivity, and ethical and security issues tied to digital databases. Morita will reassess the International Dunhuang Project as a Digital Humanities tool and introduce its potential for reconstructing art and archaeological sites by utilizing recent achievements in North America. Lastly, Harrer will focus on the visual recovery project of the Old Summer Palace (Yuanmingyuan) and evaluate its potential for advancement in preservation theory against the exclusive appreciation of the age value. The panel is followed by a discussion led by two discussants. Nagakura, an architect and director of computation group with MIT Architecture, will comment on the technology aspects of these projects. Miller will discuss these projects from an art historical perspective and explore new directions in East Asian art and architectural history with the increasing availability of digital tools.

session-title: Intralingual Translation as an Approach to Yuan-Ming Period Textual Practices
text: Under the combined pressure from a new, emerging readership and the consciousness of the diglossic nature of written Chinese, the Yuan-Ming period witnesses the flourishing of a set of textual practices that share a propensity to find new ways of preserving and transmitting textual meaning in new social and discursive environments, while creating modern forms of expression. The concept of intralingual translation is a valuable approach that reveals the unity behind very diverse textual practices, and sheds light into the fundamentally linguistic component that underlie many textual endeavors characterized by such a need for resemantization. As a relatively new concept in the field of East Asian studies, intralingual translation is the object of the first presentation by Lanselle, which reviews some of its theoretical hypotheses, as well as the reasons for which their validity applies to the specific environment of the Yuan-Ming. The following three contributions each explore different facets of this language-related epistemic reconfiguration.
