Bisettos paper focuses on an example of Yuan yanyi commentary that stresses the intrinsic continuity between commentary and translation (or auto-communication), in relation with the notion of context. Vetrov points out the importance of vernacularization as a pervasive presence that affects the very condition of philosophical expression in thinkers who, like Wang Yangming, are in search of language accuracy. Sibaus paper illustrates how, in the context of literary creation, intralingual translation plays a major role in the reshaping of textual sources in literary Sinitic. These contributions are part of an international venture currently underway.

session-title: The State of the State: Inside (and Outside) Chinas Changing Governmental
text: Recent scholarship and media reports point to a dramatic recentralization of power in China following the ascent of Xi Jinping. Though there is something to this narrative, the realities of central-local relations in China remain complex and regionally varied. This panel explores the changing governance roles and relationships of actors at different levels of the political system, addressing several related questions: What was the status quo ante of intergovernmental relations with which Chinas current cast of leaders had to grapple? How has the intergovernmental and state-society distribution of policymaking authority and resources shifted over the past decade? How should we conceptualize the relationship between Chinas political power structure and its governance architecture?  To answer these questions, panelists examine different tiers of Chinas governmental hierarchy - central, provincial, and sub-provincial - and the institutions that mediate central-local and state-society relations. The four papers highlight the mixed and sometimes counterintuitive ways political centralization affects subnational governance patterns. Maags examines the changing modes of participation by non-state actors in Chinas multilevel policymaking system using evidence from multiple localities. Wilson examines the changing personnel dynamics of municipal government during an era of conflicting economic and political pressures. Jaros and Tan highlight the resurgent development role of provincial governments at a time when much attention is focused on local economic actors and central institutions. Finally, Donaldson draws on fresh empirical evidence to adjudicate among competing theories of central-provincial power relations in China.

session-title: The Layered Body in Art: From Late Imperial to Contemporary China
text: In visual studies, scholars have studied how the body has been ritualized, gendered, dispersed and inscribed. Building on the above research, this panel considers the layered quality of the body in China from late imperial to contemporary times. We argue its layered nature invites new investigations about its susceptibility to immediate surroundings, clothing-body relationship, its medical and anthropocentric properties in connection to sexuality, physiology and emotion. Focusing on the plasticity of the body, we question not only the individuals relationship with the body and self, but also with the bodys metaphors and analogies, subjectivities, and sociability. Li explores how the banana leaf represents an exterior layer of the female body that illuminates intersections of sexual and Buddhist visions of the body. Looking at the garment as a temporal layer of the body in Qing imperial paintings, Rado reconsiders how the iconography of Chinese dress enabled the imperial body to transcend the boundaries of time. Liang examines to what extent art-anatomical books infiltrated a layered, medical gaze of the body in public debates in the early twentieth century. Focusing on a group of figure sculptures by the contemporary artist Xiang Jing, Ngan details the process by which Xiang used skin as a porous layer to materialize the genderless nature of human soul. Together the papers investigate boundaries between nature, culture and artifice .  Our discussant, Richard Vinograd, a distinguished scholar on visual representations of Chinese body, and our chair Lee Talbot, an expert of Chinese textiles, will enhance discussions of the papers.

session-title: New Media Technologies and Literary Worlding in Post-Socialist China
text: his panel investigates the intersection between new media technologies and the making of literary worlds in post-socialist China (1978-present), pivoting on two complementary lines of thinking. Firstly, how do ideas and forms associated with or generated by media technologies impact narratives and styles of literary representation? Secondly, how do technological artefacts and media systems facilitate certain modes of literary creation, circulation, and consumption?  Drawing on theoretical approaches in media and literary studies, this panel explores how digital media technologies empower Chinese netizens creativity within popular literary production. While Shao Yanjun and Xiqing Zheng focus on fans deployment of digital technologies to create a participatory literary subculture that circumvents state sponsorship and censorship, Jianqing Chen and Renren Yang canvass the power of media gadgets to forge specific styles of reading and writing. Shaos historicization of the rise of Chinese web-based fiction suggests a grassroots mode of making world literature via transnational and translingual flows of netizen labor. Zheng positions online platforms as an alternative space for fanfic prosumers to reconstruct forgotten revolutionary memories. Chen explores the impact of scrollable digital screens on the physiognomy of the narrative prose delivered therein. Yang examines a type of celebrity authorship that emerges from the structural homology between the operation of Chinas online serialization system and the progression of an action/adventure fantasy. Finally, Heather Inwood will lead a discussion on the role of the digital in so-called new media and the much-debated literariness of online fiction while opening the floor for audience participation.

session-title: Voice/Sound Studies in the China Field: Part I
text: Sound and Voice Studies are having their moment now as the acoustic turn has opened up new materials, questions, and methods. Despite some impressive recent efforts, Sound Studies, and especially Voice Studies remain emergent fields in China and tend to cluster along predictable historical and disciplinary lines. This double-panel seeks to jumpstart cross-disciplinary dialogue on voice and sound by bringing together scholars from a broad range of disciplines (music, history of science and technology, literature, film and media studies, history, and anthropology) and by bridging the divide between the advent of mechanically recorded sound. This first panel examines three radically different ways of conceptualizing the human voice at three distinct historical moments. Yiren Zhengs paper approaches the whistling of third-century intellectuals and hermits described in literary texts as a limit case that situates the voice in the gap between language, music, nature, and human agency. Judith Zeitlins study of the Qing physician Xu Dachun treats his practical, non-textual approach to singing pedagogy as a kind of techne(craft, art, technology), which instrumentalizes the body of the singer yet which exalts the operatic voice as a utopian  link to the music of antiquity. Eileen Chows paper turns from voice as sonic object to song as cultural biography. Tracing the story of an anthem composed in the 1940s for martyrs executed by the KMT as it travels from the Mainland to Taiwan and through different media over time, she emphasizes the power and meanings a song accrues through revoicing in different contexts.

session-title: Transregional Perspectives on the Taiping War and Tongzhi Restoration
text: The Taiping War looms large in any survey of modern Chinese history. Naturally, scholars focus on the Jiangnan region in particular to explain the legacies of this period, and recent scholarship has further deepened our understanding of the scars left on this area. However, because of its magnitude and geographic breadth, the effects of the war rippled across the empire. This panel will examine the Taiping War and subsequent Tongzhi Restoration from a transregional perspective. On the one hand, this means bringing attention to the experiences of regions that scholars have generally neglected or appear to have been only peripheral players in this conflict. This will enable us both to speak more authoritatively about common experiences across regions and to explain how and why local histories diverge from common narratives about the war and its aftermath. On the other hand, our panel will address the circulation of people and ideas through locales and around the empire. This is especially important in the case of the Taiping War and Tongzhi Restoration because the fighting both disrupted existing networks of exchange and created new ones. Moreover, the aftermath of the war saw the emergence of not only local activism, but also a growing sphere of elite activity on a national scale. By attending to translocal connections during the 1850s and 1860s, we can better explain the relationship between these two trends, which affected social and political developments in the last decades of the Qing.

session-title: Old Story, New Imaginations: Transmedial Representation of the past in
text: Representations of history underwent dramatic changes with the development of new media and Chinas revolutionary demands since the turn of the twentieth century. Knowledge of the past was constantly reappropriated and repackaged through transmedial circulations in response to nation building and the modernization process. In what way did the medium challenge, limit or liberate historical imaginations? This panel explores representations of the past across visual and literary media, highlighting the interconnectedness among various forms of historical narratives throughout different stages of revolution in China from the 1920s to the 1960s. The papers in this panel investigate visual, theatrical, cinematic, textual works to illuminate the creativity and fluidity in the interplay between media in representing the past. Stephanie Sus analysis of Li Yishis history painting elaborates the cinematic quality of Lis work, which was concurrent with the emerging history films in the late 1920s, as demonstrated in Yan Yuqians paper. Lis visual representation stimulated public debates on historical authenticity, particularly from Lu Xun, who also retold ancient stories. Satoru Hashimotos discussion on Old Stories Retold reveals Lu Xuns attempt at using the modern medium of fiction, particularly its rhetoric of irony, to make sense of historical rupture at Chinas modernization. Yan Yuqians case study canvasses the connections between cinema and drama, which was transformed again in wartime China. Wang Pus paper probes into the appropriation of antiquity for socialist agenda, arguing that the transmutability of allegorical-anachronistic energies indicates that media were a site of crisis and mediation during the Cultural Revolution.

session-title: Voice/Sound Studies in the China Field: Part II
text: This second part of the double panel shifts the focus from voice to sound. The four studies in this section all look at ways in which the power of sound technology is deployed to shape political space(s), from the Qing imperial court to Old Shanghai, and from the entirety of the Peoples Republic of China during the Cultural Revolution, to local communities in contemporary Taipei. The forms of technology the papers explore are equally varied and include innovation in pitch pipe measurement and a Jesuit-built organ at the Kangxi court,  commercial production, distribution, and marketing of musical records, state-issued loudspeakers and portable record players, scientific instruments for measuring sound decibels, and private audio-visual recordings.  Pursuing different methods of inquiry historical, musicological, ethnographic, technical, aesthetic the papers are careful not to impute agency to technology alone but rather raise important questions about social actors and their motives in mapping, defining, controlling, consuming, and contesting the audible world. In so doing they also develop important conceptualizations of the acoustic problems they address: territorialization and saturation (Laurence Coderre), selective memory (Andreas Steen), mediation on a global-historical scale (Zhuqing (Lester) Hu), and a technologically aspirationla approach to noise (Jennifer Hsieh).

session-title: The Origins of the Chinese Propaganda State (1937-1965)
text: This panel examines how the Communists and Nationalists built up their propaganda states so as to create intellectual fashions and transform their citizens.  Unlike other literature treating propaganda as simply ideology-inspired and self-designed rhetoric, this panel reveals how the propaganda campaigns emerged, developed, and institutionalized when the political regimes competed with and were influenced by antagonistic forces and cultures. Situating propaganda campaigns on various political settings and cultural landscapes - the Communist-controlled regions, the Nationalists-governed areas, the Japanese surrounded foreign concessions, the British colonial Hong Kong, and some cross-border spaces -- papers of this penal provide a thought- provocative comparison of different origins, discourses, apparatuses, and management of propaganda as well as the efforts of cultural workers to use propaganda to serve their political objectives. Shuge Wei scrutinizes how Sino-Japanese war shaped Nationalists propaganda system. Shensi Yi analyzes the two parties propaganda competition during the civil war. Bixiao He re-examines the little-known Hong Kong origin of the Peoples Republic of China(PRC)s private press policy. Mian Chen discusses the Communists clandestine Guangdong-Hong Kong propaganda link from 1945 to 1965. As this panel tries to emphasize, the Chinese propaganda states were woven into national and global politics and were shaped by bloody wars as well as underground networks.

session-title: Gender, Local Identity, Public Space, and Art Patronage:  New Dimensions in
text: Composed of four original studies based on new primary sources and innovative approaches, this panel explores several aspects of Chinese religion from the Ming to the present times. Despite their thematic diversity, these four studies share in their investigative focus and analysis of religion in China from the Ming to contemporary China. Secularization and its various forms from localization, socialization, through gendered modernization, and politicization of religion are explored in these new studies. Wangs paper explores the process of localization of the Pure and Bright Daoism first founded by Xu Xun during the Eastern Jin era through a locally driven cultic movement centered on a network of temples in Jiangxi. Liu reconstructs a history of Daoist patronage and practice of elite arts at a local temple in Nanyang, and finds Daoist artistic patronage practice empowering its monastic activism in shaping and assisting the social and political transformation in local society of late Qing Nanyang. Kang examines the Communist partys deployment of gender in both its anti-superstition campaigns and in its myth-making propaganda about the Partys ascending mandate and legitimacy in the late 1940s. Chaos study examines how temple-organized ritual processions not only negotiated and maintained social relations among their constituent neighborhoods, but they also helped open up tightly controlled public space for cultural and local dissent under the strictures of the authoritarian Martial Law regime in the pre-1980 Taiwan.

session-title: Green Energy, Economic Development and Environmental Governance in China
text: This panel is organized by five scholars, including Taiwan and Germany, and discusses several issues in four papers including solar and wind power in Shandong, Gansu, and Inner Mongolia. Our papers aim at exploring the research question: How did China make a balance between the development of green energy, economic development, and environmental governance? Our papers have the following findings. First, our papers observed that the green energy investment and industrial structure change did help to improve the energy efficiency and energy portfolio during the 11th Five-Year Plan and the 12th Five-Year Plan periods in Inner Mongolia. Second, our papers also found that owing to the bundled environmental policies from the central government, local governments and green company in Inner Mongolia and Shandong formulate different pattern in wind power development. Third, our papers discovered that the PV panel sectors were later embraced by the Chinese government as part of a set of industrial policies dedicated to new emerging strategic industries and an overall attempt to an increase of renewable energy use. As a result, China has emerged as a major producer of solar panels and modules as well as a major investor in solar PV installations at home. Finally, our papers realized that central government targets calling upon local governments to increase their installed capacity for wind energy and therefore now it has been substituted with targets to consume the generated power, causing local governments to attract high energy consuming industries to their regions, causing further environmental problems.

session-title: Shades of Red: Reinterpreting Chinas Early Reform and Opening Period
text: This panel challenges current interpretations about the politics of Chinas early reform and opening period. In Problems with Factions in Chinese Politics: the Case of Chen Yun, Joseph Torigian goes beyond the conventional factions account of the periods elite politics, leveraging new historical sources to reinterpret Chen Yuns relationship to Deng and his role in early economic reform policies. More broadly, the paper critiques the utility of a factions approach to understanding the elite politics of this period. In Mobilizing for Reform: Policy Experimentation and Implementation in Chinas State-owned Economy, Wendy Leutert analyzes the appropriation and creative adaptation of Mao-era mass mobilization efforts to advance market-oriented enterprise reforms. Drawing on enterprise and State Council records, she analyzes campaigns in three state firms from the 1980s through the 1990s. In China and the World Bank in the Post-Bretton Woods and Early Reform Period," Federico Pachetti demonstrates that the domestic political economy of Chinas early reforms cannot be understood without analyzing its international dimension and specifically Chinas evolving relationship with international financial institutions. Using previously unexamined materials from the World Bank Archives and Chinese published sources he demonstrates how Chinas historic decision to rejoin the World Bank in 1980 catalyzed exchanges of ideas and information, ultimately reshaping both China and the international economic system.

session-title: Making and Faking Place at Chinese Literary Gatherings
text: This panel explores the way literary gatherings and representations of those gatherings have variously imagined, shaped, and playfully reconfigured ideas of place (and time) in pre-modern China. We use the term literary gathering as a convenience to refer to elite social gatherings which served as occasions of literary production and whose occasions became the subject of literary and visual representations. Literary gatherings are manifold in East Asias cultural past. This panel measures the impact of some of these gatherings on Chinas past and offers reflections on different methodologies for their future study in China and beyond. Our papers reflect a diversity of disciplinary approaches to literary gatherings across a span of time from the fourth to the sixteenth century. Graham Chamness (PhD candidate, Harvard University) adopts an intellectual-history perspective in his examination of the fluidity of place in poems composed at a poetry composition game in fourth-century southern China. Kay Duffy (PhD candidate, Princeton University) explores the socio-ritual dimensions of a spring festival used for holding literary gatherings in the third through sixth centuries. Benjamin Ridgway (Assistant Professor of Chinese, University of Puget Sound) conducts a literary analysis of the changing meaning of scenic sites in poems composed by elites gathering around West Lake (in Hangzhou) during the Northern and Southern Song dynasties (960-1279). Lihong Liu (Assistant Professor of Art History, University of Rochester) investigates the relationship between community and local place in pictorial representations of vicinities of Suzhou produced by scholar-artists of the Ming dynasty (1368-1644).

session-title: Integrating Chinese Studies and Chinese Philosophy: Problems and New
text: This innovative methodological panel asks how current research in Chinese Studies might inform and positively influence the field of Classical Chinese Philosophy. The panelists, specialists in Comparative and Chinese Philosophy, History, Religion, and Literature, want to challenge the widespread view that notions such as the lack of author and school of thought are necessarily detrimental for pursuing philosophically oriented research. Instead, we consider the integration of textual, literary and historical knowledge in the study of Chinese Philosophy a necessary corrective for both the future of the discipline of Chinese Philosophy and an expanded, post-ethnocentric concept of Philosophy as such. The four speakers use case-studies of primary sources to highlight different aspects of this methodological and ideological issue, and to challenge one another with a clash of perspectives. Csikszentmihalyi opens with the fundamental question of how discourses about Chinese Philosophy can be adjusted to reflect destabilizing ideas such as corporate authorship. Jiang holds that, despite textual studies roles in the interpretation of Chinese Philosophy, the latter must maintain its own disciplinary norms and autonomy. Perkins, on the contrary, argues that new disciplinary norms informed by Chinese Studies will bring new opportunities to the development of Chinese Philosophy. Finally, Brindley explores how acknowledging that research in Chinese Philosophy necessitates multi-disciplinarity can help us conceive an enriched notion of Philosophy. The ten-minute, focused presentations, and the active role of the chair-discussant throughout the panel allow most of the time for discussion, encouraging timely and substantial interactions between panelists and with the audience.

session-title: Making It Real: Intercultural and Intermedia Images in Late Imperial and Early
text: The zeal and enthusiasm for verisimilitude taking place in late imperial and early republican art of China is highlighted by a burgeoning interest in the notion of actuality and knowledge-based, or machine-rendered, trustful representations. Instead of indiscriminately applying the western term realism to related art practices, this panel explores a variety of realistic, pseudo-realistic and nominally realistic paintings and photographs produced between the eighteenth and twentieth centuries in China, and opens up to a broad reflection on issues of stylization, canonization and idealization that would contradict the artworks realistic shell. How did the imported realistic approach merge and renew Chinese traditions of nonfictional representation, and how did this merging collaborate or collide with concurrent agendas and strategies of art? While the intersection of realistic representations and mannered, unrealistic elements is the panels focus, all papers address encompassing concerns relevant to intermedia practices and intercultural viewership in this period. Matters raised for discussion include gendered portrait-making practices in Qing court ideology, and the pursuit of spirit-likeness carried by a highly manipulated realistic depiction of the subjects; the conventionalized method of pairing panoramic views with serialized views of scenic spots in landscapes and the depiction of residential gardens; the integration of premodern pictorial vision, studio-based staging, and late-imperial official documentary practices in early Chinese landscape photography; and the stylization of European schemata and techniques of realistic paintings associated with the Chinese call for realism in early twentieth-century.

session-title: Displaced Youth: Migration, Education, and the Young Generations in Chinas Post-
text: From the May Fourth Movement to the present, Chinas youth has always played an important role in transforming the fate of the country. Their migration within and beyond China has powerfully shaped its sociopolitical landscape and reinforced Chinas connections to the world. Drawing upon empirical studies in anthropology, sociology, and education, our panel reveals how youths of different social statuses negotiated the structural and spatial constraints during their migration process in post-Mao China. Tracking the transnational mobility of college-age Chinese students, anthropologist Vanessa Fong (2011) has shown how Chinas youth has been ushered into the global neoliberal system through the education-migration nexus. Our panel pursues scholarly interests in youths of different social statuses and generations, and further reveals the heterogeneity of their migration patterns. Pengfei Zhaos paper examines how re-introducing merit-based examinations at the outset of the post-Mao reform occasioned rural youths transcendence of the rural-urban divide. The other three papers focus on more contemporary experiences: Anita Koo elucidates the strategies employed by the rural youth to increase their employment chances after graduation from urban vocational schools; Lisa Yiu analyzes the identities of rural migrant youth who excelled in urban public schools; Shuning Liu explores the considerations of urban elite youth when they select schools to prepare them for higher education abroad. Together the papers contribute to an interdisciplinary understanding of Chinese youths migration, as it relates to state-market dynamism in the post-Mao era beset by challenges of urbanization and globalization.

session-title: Being Ethnic in China: Representing, Deploying, and Negotiating Hui-ness
text: Being ethnic in China involves myriad discourses about individual and group identity and challenges ones competence to switch between discourses in different social-cultural and political contexts. This panel offers four case studies that analyze the ways one Chinese ethnic group, the Huis identity is represented, performed, and negotiated. Each paper focuses on forms and sites of Hui expressive culture to examine the employment of different identification discourses in various spatiotemporal settings. Sue Tuohy examines the ways that Huaer, a genre of folk songs that often is framed as a multi-ethnic genre, becomes represented as a Hui genre through labeling, narratives, and performance practices. Discussing two works written in Arabic and Chinese from the 1920s to 1950s by the Hui intellectual Ma Liangjun, Nakanishi Tatsuya suggests they reflect a switch in identification strategies to speak to different readers. Mario De Grandis analyzes modern Hui fiction writing to demonstrate how Hui authors mange in their literature to demonstrate their ethnic identity within state-approved practices by utilizing ethnic markers to promote their work, and circumvent state surveillance on religious expressions. And Yuanhao Zhao focuses on an aspect of Hui material culture, the "tangping" pitcher, examining the ways different agents employ and contextualize the pitcher to serve their own purposes and to highlight particular elements in being a Hui. These presentations examine the creative and artful ways that Hui-ness is represented, negotiated, and employed in the ongoing construction of the Hui ethnic group in China.

session-title: Moral Economies of Language in Tibet
text: Language protests have been a consistent feature of Tibetan life in China during the past decade, from self-immolations, to street protests and online petitions. These protests are an intensification of a language activism culture that pervades everyday life in contemporary Tibet, and includes extracurricular education, various forms of creative expression, as well as grassroots corpus and status planning. Previous discussions of Tibetan language politics in both academic and popular forums typically draws on a broader heuristic that portrays protest and resistance in Tibet as a direct and proportional reaction to state-led exclusion, marginalization, and stigmatization. This political economy model of Tibetan action argues that an understanding of Chinese state policies and their implementations is sufficient for understanding Tibetans actions. In this panel, we argue that this approach needs to be complemented by an examination of the moral economies of Tibetan actors: what values and moral reasoning motivate people to make particular linguistic choices, including engaging in language activism? Presenters on this panel anthropologists, linguists, and folklorists discuss the moral logic underlying linguistic activism in Tibet: who participates, for what languages and which language issues, why, and in what ways? In doing so, we not only offer new insights into an important social dynamic in contemporary China, but also offer a new approach to understanding how people make decisions about language.

session-title: The Unbearable Heaviness of Becoming: Liu Xiaobo and Chinese Political
text: I have no enemies, wrote future Nobel Peace Prize Laureate Liu Xiaobo in the closing statement for his 2009 trial that he was not allowed to deliver in court. Liu, serving an eleven-year prison term for subverting state power, died on July 13, 2017. Lius death and the tenth anniversary of Charter 08, a citizens manifesto that Liu disseminated and that led to his imprisonment, provide an occasion for reflection. Liu Xiaobos life journey is inseparable from the historical time in which he lived. From a freewheeling literary critic amidst the culture heat and political awakening of the 1980s, to a participant and a peacemaker in the 1989 Tiananmen Movement, and eventually a public intellectual devoted to Chinas peaceful democratic transformation, the last forty years of Lius life epitomized the evolution of political consciousness among Chinese intellectuals and ordinary Chinese citizens since the end of the Cultural Revolution. Lius experience was shaped by the historical context in China; at the same time, he himself became an agent for change. In death as in life, Lius name remains taboo in China. Our interdisciplinary roundtable will engage the audience in discussing Liu Xiaobos personal transformation in parallel with the making of Chinese political consciousness since the Reform Era, and the implications for China and the world. Weiping Cui, professor of Beijing Film Academy, personal friend of Liu Xiaobo, and signatory of Charter 08, will share her perspectives on Liu Xiaobo and 1980s China. Panel organizer Rowena Xiaoqing He, China-born Canadian historian specializing in the Tiananmen Movement, will focus on Liu Xiaobo in 1989; Sophie Richardson, China director at Human Rights Watch, will consider the domestic and international contexts of Charter 08 and Chinas citizens movements. Yujie Chen, Taiwan scholar focusing on criminal justice and human rights developments in Taiwan and China, will bring in her comparative perspectives from the experience of Taiwan.Panel chair Jerome Cohen, professor of Law and a leading expert on Chinese law and government, will suggest how past Chinese experiences inform the present and may influence the future.

session-title: Speed and Temporality in Asian Urban Development
text: A popular observation of Asias urban development in recent decades is that it is fast. Scholarly literatures have also begun to probe the issue of speed in urban development through the lenses of fast policy (Peck and Theodore, 2015) and fast cities (Datta and Shaban, 2015). This panel takes inspiration from this foundational work and aims to push it in new directions. Specifically, the starting point for the assembled papers is to question ostensibly universal measures of time, speed, and space that underpin much of the scholarship on urban development and that have tended to reproduce understandings of city-making in terms of GDP growth, area size expansion, population statistics, labor force and investment figures, and so forth. Such approaches risk repeating dominant discourses of development while neglecting important insights from anthropology, history, and other fields regarding concurrent multiple temporalities and modernities (Massey, 1999; Woodside). Beginning from discrete ontological critiques of time and speed, this panel is concerned with deepening the ongoing theoretical explorations of these twin dimensions as they pertain to Asias urban development. Papers will, firstly, probe time and speed in their relational complexity with the social and spatial transformations of city spaces, secondly, will bring needed attention to the politics of speed and temporality for various social groups, and finally, will expand these themes with geographically diverse contributions.

session-title: Audiences in Imperial China
text: The aim of this panel is to take a wide perspective on the nature and role of audiences in imperial China.  Audience is a manifold concept comprising, at a minimum, the audience a creator imagines for his or her work, the implied audience that emerges from the work itself, and the various actual audiences that perceive the work, either immediately and directly or in other places and future times, and in mediated or partial forms.  Our panel will examine these different dimensions, and the ways different disciplines have addressed them.  Specifically, the panels four case studies will build on recent audience-oriented scholarship in the study of China to address the following topics: What constellations of audience took shape in the fifth century literary imagination?  How did audience expectations influence Song dynasty landscape painting?  In what sense were the interrelated audiences for poetry and painting the same and how did they differ?  How might the modestly literate have perceived writing stylistically oriented toward an implied gentry audience? In keeping with our theme, this panel will have its own audience orientation.  Panelists will begin by very concisely presenting their arguments, or some salient point from their papers.  A short discussion period will follow.  Then, drawing on this audience feedback, participants will discuss a small selection of their primary sources.

session-title: The Meanings of Things: Material Culture in Middle Period China
text: Drawing on a variety of textual, visual, and historical materials, this interdisciplinary panel explores the ways in which the unprecedented interest in material things shaped the structure of knowing and learning in the Song Dynasty (960-1279).The four papers that compose the panel collectively advance two propositions: that the wider cultural changes associated with the Song cannot be understood in insolation from the physical objects that conditioned these changes; and that the history of material culture would be incomplete without consideration of its intellectual, social and aesthetic underpinnings. We progress from literary engagements with things (Huijun Mai and Yunshuang Zhang), through discussions of the material dimensions of textual production (Ya Zuo), to analyses of material processes that occurred independently of writing (Jeffrey Moser). From the biographies of scallops to the mold-marks of bronzes, we move from the wordiest effusions of materiality in the documentary record to the silent things unvoiced in texts. In so doing, we explore the ways in which things, as both subjects and objects, shaped the Song experience.

session-title: Filial Daughters in Twentieth-Century China
text: This panel investigates how womens filiality has been re-imagined in twentieth-century China as it intersects with rapidly changing gender roles and the rise of the modern woman. Even as the traditional patriarchal family came under discursive fire in the May-fourth Movement and again in Maos China, filiality as a cultural practice and ethical framework did not disappear. Instead, it underwent significant transformations, reappearing as either a social virtue of care or in the guise of mother-love. Through close analysis of poetry, biography, fiction, award petitions and field research, the four papers demonstrate that daughterly filiality remained potent and operative as Chinese women negotiated between their familial roles and public responsibilities. Some of us focus on the tension between womens pursuit of independence and social demands of elder care; some of us argue that the mother-daughter bond provided affective resources for the constructions of female subjectivity in modern China. As we engage in productive dialogue over this complex topic, it is clear that the lens of filiality allows us to observe fine nuances of womens gendered self-conception at crucial moments in Chinese modernity. Beyond individual case studies, we conceptualize the literary and political articulations of daughters filiality and the depth of its emotional and ethical appeal.

session-title: A Military Republic: The Militarization of Chinas State-Building, Nation-Building,
text: The Chinese military shaped the Republics history extensively, but not only in the form of warlordism. Its influence on Chinas state and society manifested itself in other complex ways as well: (1) Many Chinese military men were professional soldiers who had been trained to acquire a specific set of values, virtues, and behavioral patterns - and their actions were motivated by it. (2) The Republican state- and nation-building projects were characterized by strong militaristic inclinations that depicted the military man as the engine of modernization, the symbol of strong nation-statehood, and the embodiment of the qualities desired in the Republican citizen. Certain notions of professionalism and militaristic images thus amalgamated in ways that emboldened the Chinese soldier to assert his influence in areas beyond his original area of expertise. This panel argues that the actual extent to which the Chinese military influenced Republican state-building, nation-building, and modernization efforts can only be grasped when the methodologies and theoretical considerations of the fields of warlordism, militarism, and military professionalism are combined. Together, they can provide systemic insights in institutional and organizational factors that facilitated the socio-political rise of the military, in the dynamics of civil-military relations, in the preponderance of military values and considerations, and in the soldiers (self)-image, modes of thinking, conduct, and action. Each paper of this panel applies this multi-methodological approach, respectively focusing on reasons for military interference in politics, civic education in military academies, military substrata of Chinas material culture, and the armed forces obsession with modernity.

session-title: Red Chinas Green Revolution: Agricultural Modernization and Collective
text: This panel examines how changes in remuneration incentives and the spread of agricultural techniques, in particular, land terracing, increased productivity in Mao era China. Marc Blecher will chair the panel and serve as discussant. Sigrid Schmalzer will begin with a presentation on the history of terracing in Maoist China. Her paper will address how local knowledge was tapped and new technologies and techniques were successfully disseminated. Chinas research and extension system integrated land and laborsaving capital improvements and technical innovations and rewarded locally appropriate, results-driven investments. Joshua Eisenmans paper reveals how the commune extracted an increasing percentage of household savings to finance investments in productive capital and technology via this integrated research and extension system, thus kick-starting a continuous development process that produced rapid growth in food production. The workpoint remuneration system attracted members attention toward the size of their own portion relative to others and away from the extraction of their savings - a process he calls commune kabuki. Huaiyin Lis paper challenges the conventional wisdom that there was widespread shirking and inefficiency in agricultural production under the workpoint remuneration system. Li re-examines the issue of work incentives and how they constrained and motivated Chinese villagers participating in collective production. He explains the influence of non-institutional factors (i.e., local geography, demography and ecological conditions), and informal institutions (i.e., indigenous social networks, communal norms and collective sanction) on the structure of collective organization, income distribution and extraction.

session-title: Beyond the Velvet Rope: The Role of Labor in Making Chinas Heritage Sites
text: It is widely accepted that heritage is a construct, built and assembled from bits and pieces of material remains and immaterial memories to create a version of the past that satisfies modern needs and desires. But how is heritage actually made? Who are the builders and assemblers? How much of heritage is accidental, and how much planned? Heritage enterprises, even those celebrating labor, tend to draw a distinction between labor and leisure. Heritage work is typically done after hours, behind closed doors, or in fenced off areas that are closed for renovation. By obscuring the role of labor in making heritage, its managers help to preserve the mystique of heritage as eternal and natural, existing somehow independent of the human touch. Recently, however, there has been an upsurge of interest in craftsmanship and the individuals who make heritage possible. These papers contribute to this emerging understanding of heritage as something that is made every day. Elizabeth Lawrence investigates the West Lake Five Year Plan of the 1950s, explaining how socialist labor management became essential to the continuity of a scenic site traditionally associated with leisure and gentility. James Flath explores that Hanyang Iron Works, where labor productivity has been replaced by a post-industrial chic culture and creative park that nonetheless claims labor as heritage. Lisheng Zhangs study peels back the surface of the Jianchuan Museum Complex to examine who does the work of creating museums and how their labor is managed.

session-title: Cultural Traditions and Political Legitimacy in Occupied China
text: This panel investigates the uses and abuses of cultural traditions for justifying or challenging rights of governance in Japanese-occupied China. After it swiftly conquered large swaths of Chinese territory, Japan faced the challenge of political legitimization. The cultural traditions of East Asia were thus co-opted into its wartime strategies and propaganda. The Chinese client regimes, notably, were all led by classically-educated men, who also attempted to advance their own interests, often by adopting the same Pan-Asianist rhetoric while subtly alternating its meaning. This interdisciplinary panel presents four case studies. Haosheng YANG examines the adaptations and revisions of Chinese, Japanese, and Western musical and cultural traditions in the production, performance, and reception of popular music, which created an ambiguous ethnic Manchukuo (1932-45) identity. SEKI Tomohide examines the character of the much-neglected East Hebei Autonomous Council (1935-38) through its leader Chi Zongmos Confucian idealism. YUAN Yidan argues that the revival of Late Qing discourse in occupied Beijing (1937-45) in effect reflected a contest among individual memory, collective memory, and Japanese propaganda. Zhiyi YANG examines the poetic exchanges around a painting on Jing Ke, a legendary assassin, to argue that the Wang regime at Nanjing (1940-45) exploited historical memory and lyric romanticism to build a community of feelings, which supplemented their institutional weakness. In summary, through music, philosophy, historiography, and literature, the client regimes responded to the crisis in legitimacy by creative appropriations of native cultural traditions to construct new senses of identity under occupation.

session-title: Landscape, Cityscape, and Soundscape: Cold-War Literary Cosmopolitanism and
text: The Cold War era has often been associated with isolation, blockage, hostility and ideological bipolarity: even current discussion of Cold War cultural cosmopolitanism and internationalism tend to concentrate on urban regions and exclude artistic practices bridging spaces and media. Our panel revisits this critical period from literary and audiovisual perspectives in order to highlight a circulatory cultural network that transcends such ostensible binaries such as rural and urban, local and global, Left and Right, and mental and manual labor. By exploring a set of literary institutions, intertextual discourses, and Chinese writers attempts to transcend these boundaries, we reveal the multilayered historical dimensions of cosmopolitanism and internationalism in and beyond China from the 1940s to 1960s.  Zhange Ni studies how Catholic woman writer Su Xuelin negotiates her nationalist sentiments, Catholic identity, and cosmopolitan ideal through rewriting stories of Ming-Qing transition in the 1940s. Hui Xiao surveys the 1956-1966 issues of a Shanghai-based journal Budding and identifies a collective literary imagination that links local and global. Xiang Hes account of socialist writer Ru Zhijuans Lilies (1958) and The Warmth of Spring (1959) investigates the role of traditional ethical values in sustaining a life-and-death struggle and reorganizing urban space. Ling Zhangs paper examines Taiwanese leftwing writer Chen Yingzhens white terror trilogy from the perspective of acoustic memory, aiming to delineate the relations between literary soundscape, landscape, and third world internationalism. Our panel makes a contribution to the field by highlighting the intertextual and transnational cultural exchanges in spite of the Bamboo and Iron Curtain.

session-title: Remapping National Form: Center and Periphery in Artistic Canons in Socialist
text: Over the past decade, the expansion of Sinophone studies has brought increased attention within the modern Chinese studies field to artistic activities outside traditionally hegemonic centers of Chinese culture. Most notably, new research on artistic and literary production by ethnic minorities, overseas or diasporic communities, and rural people or migrants have helped to decenter the conventional centrality of Han, PRC, and urban perspectives. In this panel, we extend this approach to consider how the margins have shaped the centers in multiple ways, especially in the construction of national forms (minzu xingshi), or aesthetic practices that became state-sanctioned embodiments of Chinese culture during the socialist era. The panel focuses on the 1940s wartime period and the early PRC, examining the shifting nature and relationships of center and periphery in the formation of newly emergent artistic canons that achieved the status of socialist national forms. Each paper tackles these questions within a different artistic medium: Emily Wilcox shows how a third-generation Cantonese Trinidadian dancer, Dai Ailian, pioneered the development of Chinese dance; Charlotte DEvelyn investigates imagined references to Mongol or grassland themes in canonized musical repertoires of solo compositions for erhu; Christine Ho examines the tensions of regional inclusion and global ambition in the search for national forms in vernacular designed surfaces; and Anne Rebull analyzes the negotiations between rural representation and urban power in the filmic circulation of regional dialect xiqu plays. Overall, the papers interrogate the idea that center-periphery relations are either inherently binary or characterized by fixed power relations.

session-title: Hearing Womens Voices: Meaning-Making and Misinterpretation of Female-
text: In recent decades, scholars working across diverse disciplines have increasingly recognized the importance of gender as a socio-historically and politically significant marker influencing womens participation in different modes of cultural production as well as how those contributions were evaluated. Our panel brings together four papers that explore the diverse, and at times quite ingenious, ways in which women occupying various social roles in medieval China have fashioned for themselves meaningful modes of expression both textual and non-textual or challenged how womens voices have been ascribed delimited meanings in male-centric discourse. Rebecca Dorans paper examines examples of fuyao (ornamentation anomaly) that criticize fashions created by negatively evaluated women leaders, approaching these narratives in terms of attitudes to personal ornamentation as a communicator of identity and fuyao as a category of sumptuary regulation. Hu Qiuleis paper analyzes the dubious claims made in 4th and 5th century anecdotal literature about female authorship of pentasyllabic poetry during the late Han and early Six Dynasties period, questioning whether these attributions are less about historical reality than the exigences of later male-centered poetic practices. Wangling Jinghuas paper similarly engages issues of female authorship and anthologization, examining the practice, contributions, and erasure of the poetic voices of female entertainers within the male-dominated poetic world of the late Tang. Finally, Alexei Ditters paper looks at rare examples of female-authored muzhiming in the early Tang, and how these compositions inform us, in their own words, about womens role in the construction of memory and their experiences of death.

session-title: Creating Communities in Modern Chinese Religious Life
text: Our panel intends to examine Chinese religious communities in a variety of cultural contexts, so as to both engage with and contest existing models of community building. By comparing diverse modes of religious community in our case studies, we will address questions such as the identities of people who construct representations of religious communities, the indigenous and external origins of such ideas, similarities and differences between them, and their reception among outsiders. The paper by Kao Ya-ning explores how Zhuang shamans (mostly women) form religious communities through spiritual, professional and client networks, including the creation of ritual families. Ideas of family also lie at the core of Paul Katzs paper, which focuses on how modern lay Buddhists envisioned the familys role in building Buddhist communities and engaging with (or rejecting) non-Buddhist ones. The paper by Nikolas Broy analyzes how the Yiguandao (Way of Pervading Unity) strives to create a community of Dao followers via discourse and practice, which resembles Buddhism in extending to families, congregations, society, and the globe. Natasha Hellers paper assesses how Taiwanese textbooks represent religions role in community formation, viewing religious institutions and practices as valuable in terms of fostering common values yet downplaying their spiritual aspects. Papers will be limited to 15 minutes to allow sufficient time for our discussant (Raoul Birnbaum) to suggest key issues in the study of religious community formation and maintenance, as well as the panelists and audience to consider these issues in conversation.

session-title: Reexamining Cold War Politics in China Behind Front Lines, 1940s-1950s
text: Political, diplomatic, and military histories have long been the center of Cold War studies in the United States and China. Existing research relies largely on central government documents, and is mainly concerned with American and the Soviet influence in Chinese civil war, especially the roles of political parties and figures, diplomatic exchanges, and military strategies. This roundtable discusses new approaches and sources in the study of Cold War politics in China in the 1940s-1950s. Participants focus on how socio-cultural forces have helped shape war and its memories, using less-known or less-used primary sources. In particular, Zhiguo Yang shows that the U.S. military authorities in Qingdao were more occupied by handing daily incidents involving U.S. military personnel and Chinese civilians than supporting the Nationalist defense against encroaching Communist forces. Chunmei Du examines American military sexual violence and romance embodied in the Chinese jeep girls, focusing on how race, gender, sexuality, and class affected the daily interactions of GIs and Chinese urban civilians after World War II. Matthew Johnson introduces less visible political units and military activities including espionage and counter-espionage, clandestine propaganda campaigns, and other suasion and influence operations, to reveal complex interactions between military forces and society. Xiaobing Li suggests that Chinese and Soviet militaries in the 1950s were not only political institutes obsessed with military technologies, but also social and cultural institutes thatbelieved military modernization was part of their ongoing social revolution and political consolidation. Following the four mini-presentations, participants will first compare their discoveries with each other and discuss how their approaches differ from more traditional historiography. They will then invite audience for a dialogue, and share their extensive archival experience in mainland China, Taiwan, and the United States especially on new opportunities and challenges. For example, how to make more effective use of newly digitized municipal archives in China in the middle of tightening political control? How to better navigate the over-general index and search system in the National Archives and American military archives? The roundtable will be useful for a variety of scholars interested in Chinese history, Cold War studies, and archival research.

session-title: Art, Design, Cultural Identity and Politics: Understanding Contemporary Social
text: This multidisciplinary panel aims to connect latest academic dialogue between arts and design, cultural identity and politics. The four presenters in this panel will showcase their works on Chinese diaspora (Chinese-Canadian) regarding their identity reconfiguration and politics in the globally connected Chinese cultural landscape and in the multicultural society of Canada. The recent economic development not only turns China into one of the super powers in the global economy but also transforming the cultural landscape and the stereotypes within and outside the nation-states geographical boundary. It is evident that artists/designers often use different visual artefacts and representations (e.g., image, symbol, object) to express ideas, inner feelings, past experiences and worldviews. In other words, the creative arts can be used as a form of expression and communication. The proposed AAS panel and the four presentations seek to address the following questions: How do Chinese Canadians use different art forms and designs to express themselves and connect with others? How do Chinese Canadians consume design products such as fashion/clothing to negotiate, (re)construct, and (re)define their identity over the course of acculturation and assimilation? What role do ethnic art and cultural festivals play in a multicultural society? Are there any connections and similarities among the visual arts and designs between Canada and Greater China (Mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan)? In summary, it is reasonable to suggest that art and design play a very important role in shaping and fostering the socio-cultural values of a society (e.g., Clavier and Kauppienen, 2014; DiMaggio and FernÃ¡ndez-Kelly, 2015; Martiniello, 2015; Martiniello and Lafleur, 2008; Salzbrunn, 2014; Vanderwaeren, 2014). In order to understand the inner feeling, outward manifestation, and personal experience of ethnic minorities, scholars have used art and design as a vehicle to examine and illuminate different issues related to ethnic identity, cultural diversity, and transcultural values.

session-title: Women Were There - and Then? Gender Transformation on and Behind the Socialist
text: The concern of recuperative feminist historians to put women back into history as participants might seem irrelevant to socialist China. From the early years of the Peoples Republic, women were publicly declared an indispensable part of the workforce and the upholders of half the socialist sky. Yet the official boasts regarding womens presence and liberation are unsettling. They arrogantly covered up serious and specific questions such as: Which women were there? Where were they specifically? In what ways were they presenting themselves or being presented? For how long were they made visible? What were the womens perceptions of their presence? This socialist gender panel completes and complicates those moments in womens participation in socialist China. The papers examine different forms of womens presence and the various gestures women adopted and/or adapted in their encounter with an era that was both empowering and constraining for them. While Lunpeng Ma analyzes iconography and female subjectivity through womens screen presence as socialist exemplars, Daisy Du focuses on real socialist professional women off the screen through her research on Shanghai animation studio. Shu Yang and Mi Zhao question the states glorious promise of liberation and progress. Shu Yang discusses the rehabilitation of once negative shrewish qualities in constructing Great Leap heroines, revealing how uneasy the mass audience felt towards state strategies on gender reconfiguration. Mi Zhao examines the socialist refashioning of once disparaged singsong girls into revolutionary artists and exposes some womens desire to remain as housewives instead of dedicating themselves to socialist construction.

session-title: Civil Society with Chinese Characteristics: Emerging Forms of Citizen Mobilization
text: In the Xi Jinping era, there is ample evidence that China is heading in the opposite direction of civil society. The government is cracking down on human rights lawyers, jailing activists, and shutting down NGOs. Although these reports are accurate and disturbing, their focus on a few sensational cases may distract us from the ways that ordinary Chinese citizens are becoming empowered, and empowering others, in new ways vis-Ã -vis the state. This panel explores new forms of governmentality emerging in the PRC which allow citizen voice and mobilization. For example, the 2008 earthquake in Sichuan Province created opportunities for political participation in the affected region that linger on a decade after the disaster. Non-activist lawyers are empowering ordinary citizens to file lawsuits. There are hundreds of thousands, perhaps millions, of domestic NGOs in China, addressing social problems and lobbying the state. Some of these NGOs are partnering with the state to create new citizen empowerment opportunities. These organizations not only provide Chinese citizens new ways to mobilize, but they are going outside of the country to influence civil society in other nations. What kind of civil society is developing in China and (perhaps) being exported to the rest of the world? This panel addresses this question from multiple disciplinary perspectives, including sociology, political science, and anthropology, and it draws upon the scholarship of researchers from China, Canada, and the United States.

session-title: Chinese Dreams Along the Silk Road: Pre-histories of the Belt and Road Initiative
text: Launched in 2013, the PRCs Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is the nations latest global strategy for staving off economic crisis. Bridging development initiatives pursued across Eurasia since the 1990s, the BRI promises greater economic cooperation among the countries of Asia, Europe, and Africa through infrastructure development and enhanced free trade. For the PRC, interregional economic integration would allow the country to overcome slower economic growth, industrial overcapacity, and rising domestic labor costs. Confronting rising economic protectionism brought on by the 2008 crisis, PRC officials invoke the open spirit of economic and cultural exchange of the ancient Silk Road to foster an imaginary that renaturalizes the flows of neoliberal capitalism. Drawing on radical and conservative Chinese intellectuals writing amidst the global crisis of the 1930s and 1940s, when the collapse of the liberal market economy presented the opportunity to envision new futures for the Chinese nation and world, this panel reflects critically on what is at stake in the PRCs BRI. Jeremy Tai considers how right-wing intellectuals inspired by the American frontier story envisioned overseas Chinese returning to serve as pioneers in Chinas own virgin lands. Ana Maria Candela explores how Cantonese intellectuals drew on accounts of anti-Asian racism from the diaspora to call for the end of a world order organized by a global color line. Qian Zhu investigates how exiled Chinese leftists in Southeast Asia conceptualized a Nations Below Wind anti-colonial global alliance against the unequal distribution of wealth under capitalism and colonialism.

session-title: Gender and Christianity in Early-Twentieth Century China
text: The study of Christianity in late imperial and early Republican China has mostly focused on the missionaries. Moving beyond a simplified narrative that Christianity brought modernity to China, or a criticism of beneficent imperialism, this interdisciplinary panel brings the analytical category of gender to provide a nuanced picture how Chinese altered their relations with the church in this transitional historical moment. Focusing on indigenous responses and challenging entrenched paradigms, this panel studies images, texts and practices to (re)examine the ideals, stereotypes, and complicated realities when Christianity took root in modern China, particularly, how Chinese used Christianity to negotiate with traditional boundaries.  Based on her interviews of former missionaries and residents, Sue Gronewold examines the multiple meanings of The Pilgrims Progress (popular at the Door of Hope Mission in Shanghai) for women. William Ma traces the visual and textual appearance and evolution of the Virgin Marys image in China, focusing on how the image simultaneously took feminine roles of a mother, a seductress, and a Confucian model of womanhood. Bin Chen studies the Southern Baptist Convention (SBC) in Suzhou to investigate how Protestant schools continued and strengthened traditional rules in Chinese society, particularly gender segregation, and the responses from Chinese students. Yu Zhang examines Dora YÃ_s hymn book Fuxing shige (1909), revealing the overlapping and conflicting identities of a Christian woman from the traditional gentry class who used her faith to cover her private feelings.

session-title: Chinese Writers and Cultural Landscape in Hong Kong, 1949-1997
text: Hong Kong is an intersection where a rich variety of different socio-cultural elements clash, converge, and mingle, resulting in a unique and complex cultural landscape. During the period between 1949 and 1997, Hong Kong served as a dynamic cultural enclave for some Chinese writers who chose to get their works produced and performed there due to political and ideological reasons. These cultural productions deserve our critical attention today. The panel approaches this subject through careful analyses of several selected film and stage productions. Da Zheng studies Lady Precious Stream (1957), with a focus on its language, format, and politics in the making of this film. Karen Kingsburys paper contextualizes Eileen Changs A Tale of Two Wives (1958) in Cold War Hong Kong, analyzing the evolution and reception of that film to show its cultural importance. Wai Luk Lo takes on Yao Kes insightful adaptation of Lu Shuns True Story of Ah Q (1959), and offers a detailed comparative analysis with the narrative structure and viewpoints to reveal the complexity of the film version. Finally, Michael Cheuks paper demonstrates Gao Xingjians influence and relevance to Hong Kong theatre as well as to Hong Kong society at large. He examines Bus Stop and The Other Shore, two of Gaos plays that were staged in Hong Kong before the 1997 handover, illustrating how the playwright managed to construct a reflective theatrical space in the periphery of limited freedom.

session-title: Cultural Institutions Across Modern China
text: Institutions have long been recognized as important vectors in cultural development, change, or stability; in modern China, their power has been pervasive and, at times, oppressive. But how do cultural institutions acquire and exercise their power? And how, if at all, do their influences weaken and dissolve? This panel addresses those questions through studies in the diverse fields of theater, literature, visual art and film, all of which articulate the intricate, shifting antagonisms and alliances among established organizations, emerging networks, and individual agents, and explicate how those relationships propel or obstruct institutional functionality. He focuses on the play Wanshi shibiao to delineate how the National Drama School negotiates between literary, pedagogical and performative spaces during the Sino-Japanese War. Stuckey examines the institutionalization of Lu Xun in the Maoist era, looking specifically at the ways the iconography of Xianglin sao is deployed in an enduring story from the Great Leap period. Tan explores the institutional critique art both realized and imagined of Huang Yong Ping from the 1980s that lay bare the structural codependence between the established and the rebellious. Finally, Yang considers the Beijing Film Academys central role in the film industry of the PRC, especially an unlikely alliance between officialdom and the grassroots. Overall, the institutions construed in the papers are no longer fixed, monolithic entities, but ongoing processes with concepts, paradigms and practices that morph in reaction to particular times and spaces. The core of their power mechanism, this panel suggests, lies in their hybridity, adaptability, and porousness.

session-title: Imaged Identities: Technology, Performance, and Visual Imagination in Republican
text: The introduction of photography and printing technology radically changed the social, religious, and political landscapes of Republican China. Modern images, whether formed by camera lenses or professional painters, were more widely disseminated in mass media and helped to reshape Chinese identities in 20th century global spaces. This panel examines how photography, poster-making, and other visual propaganda embodied the experiences of Chinese people from various social classes, while also transmitting their makers interpretations of modern society. We seek to examine the ways in which Republican-era images reconfigured individual and collective identities in the contexts of religious encounters, political and social representation, and national salvation. We consider the performative aspects of image production, focusing on technical practices and perceptions that shaped visual representation. In this panel, Joseph W. Ho discusses American missionary visual practices and communications in Republican China, framing intersections between global media technologies and religious imagination in rural Hunan. Lex Jing Lu explores changing appearance standards of male political leaders and how photography replaced Chinese physiognomy, reshaping political masculinity and legitimacy-building displays in the early 20th century. Man-Hei Yip looks at Chinese Protestant propaganda posters in comparison with competing representations of national salvation offered by Nationalist and Communist groups before 1949. Matthew Combs examines social, technological, and commercial developments in the rise of Chinese amateur photography during the 1920s and 1930s. Crossing multiple thematic categories and illuminating rare source materials, this panel applies interdisciplinary methodologies in exploring often-overlooked roles of vision, visibility, and visual production in understanding Chinas recent past.

session-title: In Search of Autonomy: Chinese Intellectuals Between Politics and Scholarship
text: This panel is committed to rethinking Chinese intellectuals ambivalent stance between politics and scholarship in the post-Mao era. In the beginning of the Reform period, Chinese intellectuals were deeply inspired by Webers call to disarticulate scholarship from political utility to carve out an autonomous space for intellectual exchange. Nevertheless, an iconoclastic impulse traceable to the May Fourth Enlightenment complicated Weberian incrementalism, endowing scholarship with a decisive, even Promethean role as powerful ways of formulating radical politics, inspiring revolutions, and legitimating subversive beliefs. The metamorphosis of Chinese intellectual public space from the eighties to recent times is shaped, if not determined by, these two contradictory beliefs on politics, learning, and morality. Our panel brings together literary critics, intellectual historians, and political scientists to examine the multifaceted aspects of contemporary intellectual debates caught between politics and scholarship. Examining the interplay between Chinas intellectuals, institutionalized scholarship, and the Party-state reveals broader changes underway in intellectual-state relations.  Methodologically speaking, we are interested in the introductions of various -isms, foreign political theories to the post-Mao Chinese intelligentsia and how these theoretical arsenals help Chinese intellectuals develop powerful new discourses in political thought. This attempt goes beyond the mere study of the reception of ideas, and asks the question of how do Chinese scholars use foreign theories to write about their own subject positions between politics and scholarship? More specifically, our case studies reveal the process in which four foreign ideas neo-Kantianism, Straussianism, Schmittian statism, and utopian socialism inspired Chinese intellectuals to develop hybrid political discourses from (neo)liberalism to neo-conservatism.

session-title: Laying It Out: Late Ming Elite Cultural Productions in a Buddhist Context
text: The unprecedented extent of active lay Buddhist participation during the late Ming has been widely acknowledged yet remains understudied. In particular, this panel discusses the incorporation of Buddhist ideas, art, literary works, and ritual practices within literati culture of the time. In their Buddhist-infused cultural productions, literati developed their own particular interpretations of, and rejected, reinterpreted, expanded, or incorporated various aspects of Pure Land and Chan meditation, exegeses, and ritual to create a meaningful overlay not always aligned with received monastic practices. Each paper examines a different instance of late Ming Buddhist culture through material, artistic, dramatic, and exegetical media by which literati articulated their own positions vis-Ã -vis the dominant monastic paradigm. These four works are: a printed edition of the Diamond Sutra augmented with commentaries and illustrations for lay readers, a scroll painting used for lay meditative practice; a play that highlights the religious explorations of a playwright who, in the end, choses Buddhism over its religious competitors, and a textual commentary that reconciles Pure Land and Chan ideas partly through Wang Yangmings brand of Confucianism. Specifically, they all demonstrate how the creative repackaging of Chan texts and concepts of meditation, and arguments surrounding Pure Land rebirth broadened exposure to Buddhist ideas by inserting them in areas of literati culture where they might not otherwise have taken root and changed them in ways attuned to the cultural sphere in which each was created.

session-title: Moral Responses to Cultural Production in Modern China
text: Modern Chinese literature and film are often studied for their political, aesthetic, or commercial dimensions, but cultural production in modern China has also consistently raised significant moral issues related to social change, generation conflict, and globalization. This panel looks specifically at how literary and cinematic works in different eras (Republican, socialist, postsocialist) have given rise to debates about right and wrong, or helped to build or transform ethical value systems.  Proceeding chronologically, the panel will start with a paper by Liying Sun dealing with the introduction of Hollywood movies into China in the 1920s. She shows how these movies gave rise to moral debate about love, sex, gender, and filial piety in the popular media of the time. Hangping Xu will look at the socialist-era reception of the Russian novel How the Steel Was Tempered, focusing especially on the manner in which Chinese receptions of the male protagonist link his disability with moral exemplarity. Michel Hockx will look at the post-Mao creation of a moralistic value system for literature and art based on the concepts of truth, goodness, and beauty, tracing its influence all the way to cultural policy under the Xi Jinping regime. The panel will conclude with a paper by Xi Tian on recent changes in readership for Boys Love (BL) fiction in China and its contribution to resisting moralizing views on male homosexuality. The discussant will be Margaret Hillenbrand, whose wide-ranging research on Chinese literary and visual culture frequently touches upon themes of social and moral efficacy.

session-title: The Republic of China After 1949 and the (Re)making of Chinese Identities
text: Since its retreat to Taiwan in 1949, the Republic of China has staged itself as the legitimate international representative of China. In the second half of the twentieth century, combinations of state policies and non-official projects of cultural production forged Chinese identities on Taiwan, and through the ROCs status as Free China in the Cold War, shaped conceptions of Chinese-ness around the world. This role of the ROC, however, remains under-researched, as it does not fit into existing, territorialized frameworks for either Modern Chinese or Taiwanese history. Inspired by recent developments in Sinophone Studies, the four papers on this panel revisit the making of Chinese identities in relation to the post-1949 ROC state. Kungs paper focuses on Philippine-Chinese visits to Taiwan organized between 1958-1971, through which the Nationalist Government claimed the ROC as the motherland for overseas Chinese. Kings paper looks into how a world-renowned cookbook series written in post-war Taiwan helped redefine Chinese cuisine by including not only the four major regional cuisines of mainland China, but also a distinct category of Taiwanese cuisine. Yangs paper explores layers of Chinese identity in a popular basketball game held to celebrate Chiang Kai-sheks birthday from 1967 to 1968, in which competing teams were formed according to provinces/regions of the exiled ROC. Finally, Chus paper rewrites the complicated history of the provincial quota system in civil service examinations, which was based on the population of Chinese provinces in the early 1940s and implemented on Taiwan for more than four decades after 1949.

session-title: Beyond Ideology - Rethinking the Rhetoric of Power in Early Chinese Politico-
text: In the light of the recent developments in Chinese intellectual history, a reassessment of early forms of argument construction is required to provide a more coherent narrative of the rhetoric of power and the power of rhetoric in Early China (Pines, Goldin & Kern 2015). Following in the footsteps of most recent cutting-edge studies (Allan 2015; Kern & Meyer 2017), the panel addresses the ways in which politico-philosophical discourse is constructed at both the argumentative and the conceptual levels in early Chinese received and excavated texts. The panel explores the rhetorical use of different kinds of texts embedded within larger narratives that are imbued with political meaning, and used to express ideologically informed views complying with underlying political agendas. The panelists address the topic from different angles, focusing on the argumentative architecture or the conceptual flesh of pertinent case studies. Paul Goldin provides a reinterpretation of a set of fundamental philosophical keywords employed in politico-philosophical discourse. Andrew Meyer discusses diplomacy as a powerful rhetorical tool through an analysis of the term zongheng and its semantic field. Dirk Meyer studies the argumentative use of Shangshu traditions to produce persuasive force and concomitantly construct cultural memory in Warring States philosophical texts. Lisa Indraccolo explores the dynamics of the ruler/minister relationship as a functional rhetorical trope in early Chinese politico-philosophical debates. By integrating insights gained from different disciplines -philosophy, rhetoric, material culture, intellectual history- the panel aims to provide a fresh perspective on the argumentative strategies at play in early Chinese political philosophy.
